The installments include Dark Horizon (1994), Body and Soul (1995), Millennium (1996), The Enemy Within (1996), and The Udara Legacy (1997).

Novels 🔗

Pocket Books, a division of Simon & Schuster, published a novel series connected to the franchise starting in 1993. Judith and Garfield Reeves-Stevens, known for their work in Star Trek, wrote a novel entitled Day of Descent. Some novels served as prequels to the movie sequels, such as K.W. Jeter’s Cross of Blood, a tie-in to the Dark Horizon film, and Peter David’s Body and Soul, which became one of the sequels of the same name. The novels regularly addressed racism and discrimination with extraterrestrial themes. K. W. Jeter and Barry B. Longyear were regular contributors to the series with novels like, The Change and Slag Like Me.

Comics 🔗

From 1990 to 1992, Malibu Comics published several comics adapting the Alien Nation storyline. Among the first released titles were The Spartans, created with the help of author Bill Spangler and illustrator James Tucker, and A Breed Apart, authored by Steve Jones. Other titles included Public Enemy, authored by Sandy Carruthers and illustrated by Lowell Cunningham, and a crossover series with the Planet of the Apes franchise titled Ape Nation. The Ape Nation series included four different adventures called Plans, Pasts, Pawns and Pains along with a collector’s edition. Other contributors to the series included illustrators Terry Pallott and Leonard Kirk to titles like, The Skin Trade.

Remake 🔗

On March 25, 2015, Fox announced a remake with Art Marcum and Matt Holloway writing. On September 9, 2016, Deadline reported that Jeff Nichols would write and direct the film. On January 25, 2021, it was announced that Jeff Nichols would remake the film as a ten-part television series. On June 21, 2024, it was reported Nichols was developing an original sci-fi feature film for Paramount instead of an Alien Nation project.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Nation

item.title: Alien Apocalypse (2005 film)
item.description:
Alien Apocalypse (2005 film) 🔗

This entry describes the 2005 American science fiction TV film Alien Apocalypse.

Overview 🔗

This section presents the film’s promotional poster and basic information in a table format. Key details include:

  • Writer and Director: Josh Becker
  • Starring: Bruce Campbell, Renee O’Connor, Remington Franklin, Michael Cory Davis, and Peter Jason
  • Theme Music Composer: Joseph LoDuca
  • Country of Origin: United States
  • Language: English
  • Production: Jeff Franklin and Bob Perkis
  • Cinematography: David Worth
  • Editor: Shawn Paper
  • Production Company: Syfy
  • Original Release: March 26, 2005
  • Network: Sci Fi Channel

It establishes the film as a Sci Fi Channel original movie.

Plot 🔗

The plot summary details the events of the film:

  • Astronaut Dr. Ivan Hood (Bruce Campbell) and his companion Kelly return to Earth after a 40-year space mission.
  • They discover Earth has been conquered by giant termite-like aliens who used EMP bombs to disable the planet 20 years prior.
  • Humans are enslaved and forced to work in camps.
  • Dr. Hood and Kelly are captured near the ruins of Portland, Oregon.
  • They plan an escape after learning of a surviving President.
  • Kelly is recaptured, and Dr. Hood seeks out the President, eventually finding him a broken man.
  • Dr. Hood rallies escaped slaves to attack the alien camp and rescue Kelly.
  • The attack is successful with the help of the President’s forces.
  • Dr. Hood becomes known as “The Great Exterminator” and continues to fight the aliens.

Cast 🔗

This section lists the actors and the characters they portray in the film:

  • Bruce Campbell as Dr. Ivan Hood
  • Renee O’Connor as Lieutenant Kelly Lanaman
  • Remington Franklin as Alex
  • Michael Cory Davis as Captain Chuck Burkes
  • Peter Jason as President Demsky
  • Vladimir Kolev as Bob “Fisherman Bob”
  • Valentin Giasbeily as Tyler
  • Velizar Binev as Manager
  • Dimiter Kuzov as Bounty Hunter 1
  • Krum Iapulov as Bounty Hunter 2
  • Jonas Talkington as Bounty Hunter 3
  • Zlatko Zlatkov as Bounty Hunter 4
  • Chavdar Simeonov as Alien Leader
  • Anton Trendafilov as Jeff
  • Rosi Chernogova as Bizzy
  • Todor Nikolov as Bill “Mountain Man Bill”
  • Asen Blatechki as Crazy Man

Production 🔗

This section provides information about the film’s production:

  • The film was shot in Bulgaria.
  • Many of the actors were Bulgarian and spoke little English, requiring extensive dubbing in post-production.

It includes an image of Josh Becker directing the film.

Reception 🔗

This section summarizes the critical reception of the film:

  • Alien Apocalypse received mixed reviews from critics and audiences.
  • David Nusair of Reel Film Reviews noted that the film doesn’t take itself seriously, especially by the end.

See also 🔗

This section lists other films with similar themes:

  • Planet of the Apes (1968)
  • Battlefield Earth
  • Android Apocalypse

References 🔗

This section provides links to external sources used in the article:

  1. DVD Talk review
  2. Reel Film Reviews article

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external websites related to the film:

  • Alien Apocalypse at IMDb
  • “The Making of Alien Apocalypse” by Josh Becker
  • The shooting script for Alien Apocalypse

A navigation template for films directed by Josh Becker is also included.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Apocalypse

item.title: Alien Autopsy Fact or Fiction (1995 film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction (1995 film) 🔗

This entry discusses the 1995 pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which featured footage purporting to show an alien autopsy conducted after the Roswell incident. The footage, released by British entrepreneur Ray Santilli, was broadcast on television networks worldwide, including Fox television, hosted by Jonathan Frakes, and Channel 4 in the UK. Despite its popularity, the program was thoroughly debunked, with the footage revealed to have been shot on a set in London using plaster casts filled with offal and other materials.

Production 🔗

This section details the production of the hoaxed footage. In 2006, Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield admitted to creating the 1995 footage in a documentary presented by Eamonn Holmes. They simulated an autopsy on a fabricated alien, constructed by artist and sculptor John Humphreys in a London flat. Humphreys created two dummy alien bodies filled with raspberry jam, sheep brains, and chicken entrails. Alien artifacts were also fabricated. Santilli and Shoefield also admitted to hiring a homeless man in Los Angeles to play the role of the original cameraman.

In popular culture 🔗

This section outlines how Alien Autopsy was received and referenced in media. The X-Files satirized the footage, and Fox later aired a special debunking it. A fictionalized version of the creation of the footage was retold in the comedy film Alien Autopsy (2006).

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, news articles, and documentaries.

Further reading 🔗

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about the topic, including articles from Skeptical Inquirer and books about the Roswell incident and alien autopsy film.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources, including Ray Santilli’s “My Story” on VJ Enterprises, his IMDb page, and a YouTube link to Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction?

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_(1995_film)

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens 🔗

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and large, black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the image of Grey aliens.

Description 🔗

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are described as diminutive humanoids with grey skin, elongated bodies, small chests, and a lack of muscular definition. They are said to lack external human body parts like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their most striking feature is their disproportionately large heads with no hair and large, opaque, black eyes.

Appearance 🔗

This subsection further elaborates on the physical appearance of Grey aliens. They are generally depicted as lacking external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. Their legs are shorter and jointed differently from humans. The most prominent feature is their large, black, almond-shaped eyes, often described as lacking eye whites. They are also frequently described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli 🔗

This subsection explains the origin of the connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system. The association began with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the map showed the aliens’ home system. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and determined that the aliens’ home was Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History 🔗

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype. It notes that descriptions of beings similar to Greys predate alien encounter claims, citing H.G. Wells’ descriptions of future humans in “The Man of the Year Million” (1893) and the Eloi in “The Time Machine” (1895).

Origins 🔗

This subsection explores the literary and occult origins of the Grey alien concept. H.G. Wells’ depictions of future humans and the Eloi are mentioned as early examples of beings with Grey-like characteristics. Aleister Crowley’s 1917 encounter with a “preternatural entity” named Lam, described as similar to a modern Grey, is also discussed. Gustav Sandgren’s 1933 science fiction novel, Den okända faran (The Unknown Danger), which describes a race of extraterrestrials with grey skin, bald heads, and large eyes, is identified as a key influence on the modern image of Grey aliens.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction 🔗

This subsection focuses on the Barney and Betty Hill abduction case and its role in popularizing the Grey alien archetype. The Hills claimed that in 1961, they were abducted by grayish-skinned humanoid beings and taken aboard a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer’s 1990 article suggests that Barney’s memories, revealed under hypnosis, may have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield,” which featured an alien with large eyes. Carl Sagan echoed these suspicions, citing Invaders from Mars as another potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore 🔗

This subsection discusses how Grey aliens became an integral part of ufology and extraterrestrial-related folklore after the Hill’s encounter. Journalist C.D.B. Bryan notes that 73% of reported alien encounters in the United States describe Grey aliens. The section also mentions the alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947, and claims that individuals saw the U.S. military handling child-sized beings with oversized heads and slanted eyes. Whitley Strieber’s 1987 book Communion, which described his alleged encounters with Greys, is also discussed. Jimmy Guieu’s 1988 interview on TF1’s Ciel, mon mardi! introduced the term “the little greys” to the French public.

The section further notes that Greys have become the subject of many conspiracy theories, with some theorists believing they are part of a government disinformation campaign or a product of mind-control experiments. Ray Santilli’s 1995 film Alien Autopsy, which claimed to depict the autopsy of a “real” Grey, is also mentioned.

Analysis 🔗

This section examines various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology 🔗

This subsection analyzes the role of Greys in alien abduction claims. It notes that Greys make up a significant percentage of reported alien encounters in various countries. Abduction claims are often described as traumatic, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes of the Greys are often a focus of abduction claims, with abductees reporting that the Greys stare into their eyes during mental procedures.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence 🔗

This subsection presents neurologist Steven Novella’s theory that Grey aliens are a byproduct of the human imagination, with their distinctive features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” 🔗

This subsection discusses Frederick V. Malmstrom’s “Mother Hypothesis,” which suggests that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development. Malmstrom argues that the face of a Grey can be reconstructed through transformation of a mother’s face based on early-childhood sensation and perception.

Evolutionary implausibility 🔗

This subsection presents biologist Jack Cohen’s argument that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses 🔗

This subsection briefly mentions alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of alleged Grey aliens, including the interdimensional hypothesis, the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, and the time-traveler hypothesis.

In popular culture 🔗

This section explores the depiction of Grey aliens in popular culture. It notes that Greys have become a common way to depict extraterrestrials in fiction, supplanting the “little green men” archetype. Examples include Ultraman (1966), Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Babylon 5, Stargate, and South Park. The section also mentions the increasing association of Greys with conspiracy theories in the 1990s, citing The X-Files as a prominent example. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The films Paul (2011) and Dark Skies (2013) are also mentioned, as well as the TV series Resident Alien (2021) and the game Greyhill Incident (2023).

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_aliens

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens 🔗

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulians, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the image of Grey aliens.

Description 🔗

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are described as diminutive humanoid beings with grey skin, lacking external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition, and having disproportionately short legs. A key feature is their large heads relative to their bodies, devoid of hair, with small orifices for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their eyes are large, opaque, black, and almond-shaped. They are often described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli 🔗

The connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system stems from Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the map showed the aliens’ home system. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and identified the stars as Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History 🔗

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype.

Origins 🔗

Descriptions of beings resembling Grey aliens predate reported encounters. H.G. Wells described future humans with similar features in his 1893 article “The Man of the Year Million” and his 1895 novel The Time Machine. In 1917, Aleister Crowley described an entity named Lam with a similar appearance. In 1933, Swedish novelist Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, described aliens with grey clothes, bald heads, and large eyes in his science fiction novel The Unknown Danger.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction 🔗

The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 brought the Grey alien archetype to public attention in 1965. The Hills claimed they were abducted by grey-skinned humanoids and taken aboard a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer suggested Barney’s memories, revealed under hypnosis, may have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield,” which aired shortly before Barney’s first hypnotic session. Carl Sagan also suggested Invaders from Mars as a potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore 🔗

Following the Hill’s encounter, Greys became a central figure in ufology and extraterrestrial folklore, particularly in the United States, where they account for 73% of reported alien encounters. The alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947, was later linked to Greys. In 1987, Whitley Strieber published Communion, a book detailing his alleged encounters with Greys, which became a bestseller and was adapted into a film. In 1988, Jimmy Guieu introduced the term “les Petits-Gris” (little greys) to French audiences.

Greys have become the subject of conspiracy theories, with some theorists believing they are part of government disinformation campaigns or mind-control experiments. Ray Santilli claimed to have obtained film footage of an autopsy of a “real” Grey recovered from Roswell, but later admitted it was a “reconstruction.”

Analysis 🔗

This section explores various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology 🔗

Greys are frequently associated with alien abduction claims, accounting for a significant percentage of reported encounters in various countries. Abduction claims are often described as traumatic, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes of the Greys are often a focal point, with claims of inducing hallucinogenic states or emotions through staring.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence 🔗

Neurologist Steven Novella suggests that Grey aliens are a product of the human imagination, with their features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” 🔗

Frederick V. Malmstrom proposes that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development, reconstructing the face of a Grey through transformation of a mother’s face.

Evolutionary implausibility 🔗

Biologist Jack Cohen argues that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses 🔗

The interdimensional, cryptoterrestrial, and time-traveler hypotheses offer alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of these alleged beings.

In popular culture 🔗

This section highlights the presence of Grey aliens in various forms of media.

Grey aliens have become a common depiction of extraterrestrials in fiction, replacing the earlier “little green men.” They have appeared in films and television shows such as Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Babylon 5, and Stargate. During the 1990s, plotlines linking Greys to conspiracy theories became prevalent, as seen in The X-Files. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The film Paul features a Grey alien who attributes the Greys’ presence in pop culture to government manipulation. The film Dark Skies features child abduction by Greys. Greys also appear in the TV series Resident Alien and the game Greyhill Incident.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_alien

item.title: Alien
item.description:
Alien 🔗

The Alien franchise is a science fiction horror and action media franchise that began with the 1979 film Alien. The series centers on Ellen Ripley’s battles with the extraterrestrial Xenomorph and the prequel series following the android David 8 and the Engineers. The franchise is owned by 20th Century Studios.

Created by: Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett Original Work: Alien (1979) Owner: 20th Century Studios Years Active: 1979–present

Premise 🔗

The franchise depicts deadly encounters between humanity and the Xenomorph, a hostile extraterrestrial species. Humanity is a space-faring species, and space journeys require cryosleep. The megacorporation Weyland-Yutani Corp seeks to profit from the Aliens, manipulating and endangering characters. The series also explores the origin of the human race, with the Engineers sacrificing themselves to spark the genesis of mankind.

Background 🔗

Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett collaborated on the script for Alien. Brandywine Productions bought the script, and 20th Century Fox invested millions after the success of Star Wars. The Ripley character was initially to be played by Tom Skerritt, but Sigourney Weaver was cast instead. Ridley Scott directed the film. H. R. Giger designed the alien creature and derelict ship, Mœbius created the spacesuits, and Ron Cobb provided the industrial design for the sets.

James Cameron expressed interest in continuing the Alien story in 1983. After Cameron’s The Terminator became a hit, he and Gale Anne Hurd were approved to direct and produce Aliens. Following the second film, Weaver was not interested in returning, but she was offered a $5 million salary and a producer credit to make Alien 3. Alien 3 faced script difficulties, trouble securing a director, and studio interference.

Production on Alien Resurrection began in 1996. Weaver joined the project after being offered an $11 million salary and more creative control. The script resurrected the Ripley character via human cloning. Joss Whedon later said that he thought it had done “everything wrong” with his script.

Films 🔗

This section lists the Alien films, including the original series, Alien vs. Predator films, and Prometheus films. It includes the U.S. release date, director, screenwriter(s), story by, and producer(s) for each film.

Original series 🔗

  • Alien (1979): Directed by Ridley Scott, starring Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley. The crew of the Nostromo encounters a deadly alien creature.
  • Aliens (1986): Directed by James Cameron, Ripley returns to LV-426 with a squad of marines to investigate a lost colony.
  • Alien 3 (1992): Directed by David Fincher, Ripley crash-lands on a prison planet and faces a new alien threat.
  • Alien Resurrection (1997): Directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet, Ripley is cloned 200 years after her death, and the military attempts to exploit the Aliens.

Crossover series 🔗

  • Alien vs. Predator (2004): Directed by Paul W. S. Anderson, a group of explorers discovers an ancient pyramid in Antarctica, where they become caught in a battle between Aliens and Predators.
  • Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem (2007): Directed by Greg & Colin Strause, the Predalien hybrid from the previous film causes a Predator ship to crash in Gunnison, Colorado, leading to a battle between Aliens and a Predator.

Prequel series 🔗

  • Prometheus (2012): Directed by Ridley Scott, scientists Elizabeth Shaw and Charlie Holloway discover a star map and travel to LV-223, where they encounter the Engineers.
  • Alien: Covenant (2017): Directed by Ridley Scott, the crew of the Covenant traces a transmission to an Engineer homeworld, where they encounter David 8 and a new breed of Alien.

Spin-off film 🔗

  • Alien: Romulus (2024): Directed by Fede Álvarez, set between Alien and Aliens.

Future 🔗

Discusses potential future installments in the Alien franchise, including a cancelled Alien 5 project by Neill Blomkamp and ongoing development of new films.

Short films 🔗

This section lists the Alien short films, including the U.S. release date, director(s), screenwriter(s), and producer(s) for each film.

Television and web series 🔗

This section lists the television and web series in the Alien franchise, including the season, episodes, originally released dates, network, showrunner(s), and status for each series.

  • Alien: Isolation – The Digital Series (2019): A seven-episode animated adaptation of the video game Alien: Isolation.
  • Alien: Earth (2025): A new TV series project based on the franchise, set on Earth in the near future.

Cast and crew 🔗

This section lists the principal cast and additional crew members involved in the Alien franchise.

Principal cast 🔗

Lists actors and the characters they portrayed in the films, web series, television series, and audio dramas. Key actors include Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley, Ian Holm as Ash, Lance Henriksen as Bishop II Michael Bishop Weyland, Carrie Henn as Rebecca “Newt” Jorden, Michael Biehn as Dwayne Hicks, Noomi Rapace as Elizabeth M. Shaw, and Michael Fassbender as David 8.

Additional crew 🔗

Lists the composers, cinematographers, editors, production companies, and distributors for each Alien film.

Reception 🔗

This section discusses the box office performance, critical and public response, and accolades received by the Alien films.

Box office performance 🔗

Provides a table of the box office revenue for each Alien film, including North America, foreign, and worldwide totals, as well as the budget for each film.

Critical and public response 🔗

Provides a table of the critical and public response to each Alien film, including Rotten Tomatoes scores, Metacritic scores, and CinemaScore grades.

Accolades 🔗

Lists the Academy Award nominations for Alien films.

Alien Day 🔗

Discusses “Alien Day,” the fan celebration day for the Alien franchise on April 26.

Alien: The Play 🔗

Discusses the North Bergen High School’s adaptation of Alien entitled Alien: The Play, which was widely praised.

In academia 🔗

Discusses the Bishop character as a high-profile android character conforming to Isaac Asimov’s Three Laws of Robotics.

Music 🔗

Lists the soundtracks for Alien films, including the U.S. release date, length, composer(s), and label for each soundtrack.

Home media 🔗

Discusses the various home media releases of the Alien films, including VHS, Laserdisc, DVD, and Blu-ray.

Other media 🔗

This section discusses spin-offs in other media, including crossovers with the Predator franchise.

Print media 🔗

Discusses Alien print media, including novelizations of the films, original content that expand upon the fictional universe, comics, and companion books.

Novels 🔗

Lists several novelizations of each of the six films and some comic books as well as original canonical novels based on the franchise have been released.

Comic books 🔗

Discusses the numerous limited series set in the Alien universe, as well as non-canonical crossover appearances of the Alien.

Picture books 🔗

Discusses Jonesy: Nine Lives on the Nostromo, a 2018 picture book that retells the plot of Alien (1979) from the perspective of Jones, the ship’s cat from the film.

Video games 🔗

Discusses the numerous video games released over the years, spanning a variety of genres.

Merchandising 🔗

Discusses the merchandise manufactured and marketed to a wide range of age groups.

Theme park attractions 🔗

Discusses the Alien-themed attraction at the Genting SkyWorlds Theme Park in Malaysia and The Great Movie Ride at Disney’s Hollywood Studios.

Alien vs. Predator franchise 🔗

Discusses the Alien vs. Predator franchise, inspired by the Dark Horse Comics series.

The Predator (2018) 🔗

Discusses the alternate endings of Shane Black’s The Predator (2018), which featured Ellen Ripley and Rebecca “Newt” Jorden.

See also 🔗

Lists related topics, including space science fiction franchises, films featuring extraterrestrials, and monster movies.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_(franchise)

item.title: Pentagon UFO videos
item.description:
Pentagon UFO Videos 🔗

This article discusses the widely publicized cockpit instrumentation display videos from US Navy fighter jets, often characterized as UFOs.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the videos, referencing historical UFO photographs and events. It details the initial incident on November 14, 2004, involving Commander David Fravor of the USS Nimitz Carrier Strike Group investigating radar indications of a possible target off the coast of southern California. The USS Princeton had been tracking unusual aircraft for two weeks prior to the incident. Fravor’s account of encountering a white, oval object hovering above an ocean disturbance is highlighted, as well as the observations of other pilots. It also mentions Lieutenant Commander Chad Underwood, who recorded the “FLIR” video and coined the term “Tic Tac” to describe the object. The section also mentions the 2014-2015 incidents involving fighter pilots associated with the USS Theodore Roosevelt carrier strike group operating off the East Coast of the United States, during which the GIMBAL and GOFAST videos were recorded.

Release of Videos 🔗

This section focuses on the public release of the videos. The New York Times reported on the incidents and published the “FLIR” and “GIMBAL” videos in December 2017, while the Washington Post published the “GOFAST” video. Christopher Mellon, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence, provided the videos to the press. Luis Elizondo, the director of the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, resigned from the Pentagon in October 2017 to protest government secrecy. In September 2019, the Pentagon confirmed the videos were made by naval aviators. On April 27, 2020, the Pentagon formally released the three videos. In February 2020, the United States Navy confirmed that intelligence briefings have been provided to members of Congress.

2021 Release 🔗

This section details the release of additional footage in 2021. In April 2021, the Pentagon confirmed the authenticity of a video taken by Navy personnel aboard USS Russell in 2019, showing a triangular object. Mick West suggested the image was the result of an optical effect called a bokeh. The Pentagon also confirmed photographs of objects described as “sphere”, “acorn” and “metallic blimp”. In May 2021, a second video recorded by Navy personnel aboard the USS Omaha on July 15, 2019, was confirmed and is under review by the UAP Task Force. The video purportedly shows a spherical object flying over the ocean. Mick West commented on the video, suggesting it could simply be a plane.

2023 Release 🔗

This section covers the release of additional videos in 2023. In early 2023, an object was filmed by two MQ-9 drones in South Asia, initially believed to be anomalous but later identified as a commuter aircraft. On May 31, 2023, Sean M. Kirkpatrick shared an infrared video recorded in the western United States in 2021, which AARO concluded to be commercial aircraft. On April 19, 2023, the Pentagon released another video featuring MQ-9 drone footage from the Middle East depicting an unidentified aerial phenomenon resembling a small “metallic orb”. Sean M. Kirkpatrick briefed a Senate Armed Services subcommittee on the video, but stated they are unable to fully identify anything from the video.

Potential Explanations 🔗

This section explores potential explanations for the aerial phenomena recorded in the videos. As of 2020, the Department of Defense characterizes the phenomena as “unidentified”. Skeptical explanations include instrument malfunction, human observational error, or common aircraft. Mick West cautioned that believers in “alien disclosure” are “encroaching on these real issues of UAPs”. Adam Frank speculated that the UFOs could be drones deployed by rivals like Russia and China. Thomas Bania speculated that they could be some form of electronic warfare fielded by China or Russia. The US Navy updated its reporting guidelines for unexplained aerial observations. Senator Marco Rubio expressed concern that the UFOs may be Chinese or Russian technology. Admiral Gary Roughead said that most assessments were inconclusive. Jeff Wise suggests advancements in electronic warfare could deceive sensors. In 2023, David Fravor testified under oath regarding the USS Nimitz sighting, stating that the technology was far superior to anything the US had.

June 2021 UFO Report 🔗

This section discusses the preliminary report on UAPs released by the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) on June 25, 2021. The report came to no conclusion about what the UAPs were, citing a lack of sufficient data. Some UAPs appeared to exhibit unusual flight characteristics, including high velocity and maneuverability. The report indicated that the UAP recordings probably were of physical objects and proposed five possible categories of explanation: airborne clutter, natural atmospheric phenomena, US government or industry development technology, foreign craft, and an “Other” category. The report raised concerns about safety and security issues and indicated that investigation of the topic would continue.

FOI Request by The Black Vault 🔗

This section details a Freedom of Information request made by The Black Vault for the release of more video footage. The government confirmed it had more footage but refused to release it, citing concerns for national security. Gregory Cason stated that the release of this information would harm national security.

In Popular Culture 🔗

This section notes the videos’ appearance in the History Channel series Unidentified: Inside America’s UFO Investigation and an interview with Fravor on The Joe Rogan Experience.

See Also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force, All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, Navy UFO patents, and the film The Phenomenon.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentagon_UFO_videos

item.title: Pentagon UFO videos
item.description:
Pentagon UFO videos 🔗

The Pentagon UFO videos are visual recordings from United States Navy fighter jets, widely publicized as UFOs. These videos were recorded using forward-looking infrared (FLIR) targeting cameras from fighter jets based aboard the aircraft carriers USS Nimitz and USS Theodore Roosevelt in 2004, 2014, and 2015. Additional footage was taken by other Navy personnel in 2019. The videos, characterized as officially documenting UFOs, have received extensive media coverage since 2017. The Pentagon officially released the first three videos of unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) in 2020 and confirmed the provenance of the leaked 2019 videos in 2021. Footage of UAPs was also released in 2023, sourced from MQ-9 military drones.

Publicity surrounding the videos has prompted explanations including drones or unidentified terrestrial aircraft, anomalous instrument readings, physical observational phenomena, human observational and interpretive error, and speculations of alien spacecraft.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Pentagon UFO videos, referencing the broader history of UFO sightings and investigations. It mentions UFO photographs and links to other Wikipedia articles on the topic.

On November 14, 2004, Commander David Fravor of the USS Nimitz Carrier Strike Group investigated radar indications of a possible target off the coast of southern California. Fravor reported seeing a white, oval object hovering above an ocean disturbance. A second wave of fighters, including Lieutenant Commander Chad Underwood, recorded the FLIR video, with Underwood coining the term “Tic Tac” to describe the infrared image.

During 2014–2015, fighter pilots associated with the USS Theodore Roosevelt carrier strike group recorded the GIMBAL and GOFAST videos while operating off the East Coast of the United States.

Release of videos 🔗

This section details the public release of the videos and the reactions that followed.

On December 16, 2017, The New York Times reported on the incidents and published two videos, “FLIR” and “GIMBAL.” The Washington Post published a video titled “GOFAST.” The reports led to speculation by UFO investigators. Journalism professor Keith Kloor criticized the reporting as thinly-sourced and slanted.

The videos were initially provided to the press by Christopher Mellon, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence. Luis Elizondo, the director of the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, resigned from the Pentagon in October 2017 to protest government secrecy.

In September 2019, the Pentagon confirmed that the released videos were made by naval aviators. On April 27, 2020, the Pentagon formally released the three videos. In February 2020, the United States Navy confirmed that intelligence briefings have been provided to members of Congress.

2021 release 🔗

This section covers the release of additional videos and images in 2021.

In April 2021, the Pentagon confirmed that video footage of an unidentified triangular object taken by Navy personnel aboard USS Russell in 2019 was authentic. Mick West suggested the image was the result of an optical effect called a bokeh. The Pentagon also confirmed photographs of objects described as “sphere”, “acorn” and “metallic blimp”.

In May 2021, the Pentagon confirmed a second video recorded by Navy personnel aboard the USS Omaha on July 15, 2019, showing a spherical object flying over the ocean. Mick West commented that the object was likely a plane.

2023 release 🔗

This section describes the release of additional footage in 2023, including analysis of the objects.

In early 2023, an object was filmed by two MQ-9 drones in South Asia. Initially believed to be anomalous, the object was later identified as a commuter aircraft.

On May 31, 2023, Sean M. Kirkpatrick shared an infrared video recorded in the western United States in 2021, which the AARO concluded to be commercial aircraft.

On April 19, 2023, the Pentagon released another video featuring MQ-9 drone footage from the Middle East depicting an unidentified aerial phenomenon. Sean M. Kirkpatrick briefed a Senate Armed Services subcommittee that it resembled a small “metallic orb” but said they are unable to fully identify anything from this video. Some skeptics suggested it might be a balloon.

Potential explanations 🔗

This section discusses potential explanations for the aerial phenomena recorded in the videos.

As of 2020, the Department of Defense characterizes the phenomena as “unidentified.” Widespread media attention has led to various theories, including pseudoscientific explanations such as ufology.

Skeptical explanations include instrument malfunction, human observational illusion, or common aircraft. Mick West cautioned that believers in “alien disclosure” are encroaching on real issues and that the recorded UFOs might be commercial airplanes or balloons distorted by infrared glare.

Astrophysicist Adam Frank speculated that the UFOs could be drones deployed by rivals like Russia and China. Astronomer Thomas Bania speculated that they could be electronic warfare technology.

The US Navy updated its guidelines for reporting unexplained aerial observations. A spokesman suggested that the increase in reported intrusions could be due to the rise in availability of unmanned aerial systems.

Senator Marco Rubio expressed concern that the UFOs may be Chinese or Russian technology. Retired Admiral Gary Roughead said that most assessments were inconclusive.

Adam Dodd and security expert Jack Weinstein say that neither China nor Russia presently have the capability to produce aircraft with such extraordinary capabilities.

Jeff Wise suggested that advancements in electronic warfare techniques could deceive sensors, resulting in false velocity and position information.

In 2023, David Fravor testified under oath that the technology they faced was far superior to anything they had.

June 2021 UFO report 🔗

This section summarizes the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) preliminary report on UAPs released on June 25, 2021.

The report came to no conclusion about what the UAPs were, citing a lack of sufficient data. In a limited number of incidents, UAP appeared to exhibit unusual flight characteristics. Some of the UAPs appeared to move with no discernible means of propulsion.

The report indicated that, in most cases, the UAP recordings probably were of physical objects. The report proposed five possible categories of explanation: airborne clutter, natural atmospheric phenomena, US government or industry development technology, foreign craft, and an “Other” category.

The report raised concerns about safety and security issues and indicated that investigation of the topic would continue.

FOI request by The Black Vault 🔗

This section discusses a Freedom of Information request made by The Black Vault for the release of more video footage.

In April 2020, The Black Vault made a Freedom of Information request to the US Navy. The government confirmed it had more footage but refused to release it, citing concerns for national security.

In popular culture 🔗

This section notes the appearance of the videos in popular media.

The videos were featured in the 2019 History Channel series Unidentified: Inside America’s UFO Investigation. Episode 1361 of The Joe Rogan Experience featured the videos and interviewed Fravor.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Theodore_Roosevelt_UFO_incidents

item.title: Barney and Betty Hill incident
item.description:
Barney and Betty Hill Incident 🔗

This Wikipedia article details the alleged alien abduction of Barney and Betty Hill in 1961, a case that gained significant notoriety and influenced the alien abduction narrative. The article covers the background of the Hills, the details of their reported encounter, the aftermath, analysis of the star map Betty Hill claimed to have seen, and the cultural impact of their story.

Background 🔗

Barney and Betty Hill were an interracial couple living in Portsmouth, New Hampshire. Barney was a postal worker and Betty was a social worker. They were active in civil rights and community affairs. The article also mentions that they are the grandparents of UFC fighter Angela Hill.

UFO Encounter 🔗

On September 19-20, 1961, the Hills claimed to have encountered a UFO while driving back from a vacation in Canada. Near Lancaster, New Hampshire, Betty noticed a bright light in the sky. They stopped near Twin Mountain to observe the object, which Betty viewed through binoculars. Barney initially thought it was a commercial airliner, but it rapidly descended towards them. They continued driving, observing the object near Cannon Mountain and the Old Man of the Mountain. South of Indian Head, the object descended rapidly, causing Barney to stop the car. He observed humanoid figures through binoculars. Fearing capture, Barney ran back to the car, and as they drove away, they heard beeping sounds and experienced a daze. They reported the incident to NICAP investigator Walter Webb.

Immediate Aftermath 🔗

Upon arriving home, the Hills noted odd sensations and unexplained occurrences. Betty insisted on keeping their luggage near the back door. Their watches stopped working. Barney found the binocular strap torn and his shoes scraped. They both took showers to remove possible contamination and drew pictures of what they had seen. Betty’s dress was torn and had a pinkish powder on it. Shiny, concentric circles appeared on their car’s trunk, which affected a compass.

Initial Report to the U.S. Air Force and NICAP 🔗

Walter N. Webb, a Boston astronomer and NICAP member, interviewed the Hills. Barney mentioned a “mental block” and suspected he was suppressing parts of the event. Webb concluded that they were truthful, and the incident likely occurred as reported.

Betty’s Dreams 🔗

Ten days after the encounter, Betty began experiencing vivid dreams for five consecutive nights. In her dreams, they encountered a roadblock and were forced into a forest by small men in blue uniforms. The men appeared nearly human with greyish skin. They were eventually returned to their car and watched the craft depart.

Medical Help and More Interviews 🔗

The Hills sought medical help to understand their experience.

Missing Time 🔗

During a follow-up interview with NICAP members C.D. Jackson and Robert E. Hohmann, the Hills realized they had “missing time” – a period of about seven hours they couldn’t account for. They recalled almost nothing of a 35-mile stretch of road and an image of a fiery orb.

Private Disclosure 🔗

In 1962, the Hills privately disclosed their encounter to Captain Ben H. Swett of the United States Air Force, who was interested in the “missing time” aspect.

Simon’s Hypnosis Sessions 🔗

The Hills underwent hypnosis with Dr. Benjamin Simon to recover their memories.

Barney’s Sessions 🔗

Under hypnosis, Barney recalled the binocular strap breaking as he ran from the UFO. He remembered being compelled to drive into the woods and seeing six men. He described the beings’ terrifying eyes and their communication through “thought transference.”

Betty’s Sessions 🔗

Betty’s account under hypnosis was similar to her dreams, with some differences. The technology on the craft was different, the short men differed significantly in physical appearance and the sequential order of the abduction differed. Barney’s and Betty’s memories in hypnotic regression were consistent with one another.

Simon’s Conclusions 🔗

Dr. Simon concluded that the case was a psychological aberration.

Post-Hypnosis Publicity and Barney’s and Betty’s Death 🔗

The Hills initially kept a low profile. However, in 1965, a front-page story in the Boston Traveller revealed their story, leading to international attention. John G. Fuller wrote the book The Interrupted Journey about the case in 1966. Barney died in 1969, and Betty became a figure in the UFO community. Betty died in 2004.

Analyzing the Star Map 🔗

In 1968, Marjorie Fish, an amateur astronomer, attempted to decipher the star map Betty Hill had drawn. Fish constructed a three-dimensional model of nearby Sun-like stars and concluded that the map’s perspective matched the Zeta Reticuli star system. The analysis was debated, with Carl Sagan arguing it was a random alignment of points. Later, more accurate data from the Hipparcos mission led Fish to reject her hypothesis.

Interrupted Journey 🔗

The 1966 book Interrupted Journey by John G. Fuller detailed the Hills’ claims. Betty Hill’s niece, Kathleen Marden, further explored these themes in Captured! The Betty and Barney Hill UFO Experience.

Rebutting the Hills 🔗

Jim Macdonald argued that the Hills’ experience was caused by misinterpreting an aircraft warning beacon on Cannon Mountain, combined with stress, sleep deprivation, and false memories. Robert Sheaffer criticized Betty Hill’s credibility, citing her UFO photos and later delusional stories.

Influence from The Outer Limits 🔗

Martin Kottmeyer suggested that Barney’s memories might have been influenced by “The Bellero Shield,” an episode of The Outer Limits. Jason Colavito pointed out other episodes of The Outer Limits that aired before Barney’s hypnosis sessions that were even more reminiscent of the Hill’s story.

In Popular Media 🔗

The Hills’ story has been depicted in various forms of media.

Nonfictional Accounts 🔗

Barney Hill appeared on To Tell the Truth in 1966. Kathleen Marden and Stanton Friedman authored Captured in 2004.

In Fiction 🔗

The 1975 film The UFO Incident dramatized the Hills’ abduction. The story has also been referenced in comic books, films like Prometheus, virtual reality exhibits, and television series like Project Blue Book.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betty_and_Barney_Hill_abduction

item.title: List of humanoid aliens
item.description:
List of Humanoid Aliens 🔗

This Wikipedia entry is a compilation of fictional extraterrestrial humanoid characters from various media. It emphasizes that these aliens possess human-like traits such as upright posture, bipedalism, opposable thumbs, and facial features. The list is organized by medium: Animation, Comics, Film, Literature, Television, and Video Games. Each entry includes the character’s name, origin (the work in which they appear), and brief notes about their role or characteristics. The article is flagged as needing additional citations for verification and may not be complete.

Animation 🔗

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in animated works. Key characters include:

  • The Great Gazoo (The Flintstones): A tiny alien exiled to Earth who can only be seen by Fred, Barney, children, and animals.
  • Cure Princess/Hime Shirayuki (HappinessCharge PreCure!): A princess from the Blue Sky Kingdom.
  • Mikitaka Hazekura (JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure): An alien who appears as a teenage boy with pointed ears.
  • Interplanet Janet (Schoolhouse Rock): A cyborg girl from another galaxy.
  • Jet Propulsion (Ready Jet Go!): An alien from Bortron 7 studying Earth.
  • Cure Milky/Lala Hagoromo (Star Twinkle PreCure): An alien from the planet Samaan.
  • Little Twelvetoes (Schoolhouse Rock): A jovial alien with green skin and six fingers and toes.
  • Marvin the Martian (Looney Tunes): A Martian often accompanied by his dog K-9.
  • Ozmodiar (The Simpsons): A parody of The Great Gazoo, only visible to Homer Simpson.
  • Roger (American Dad!): An alien living in Stan’s attic.
  • Sailor Starlights (Sailor Moon): Sailor Guardians from Planet Kinmoku.
  • Shadow Galactica (Sailor Moon): Antagonists from various planets in the Milky Way.
  • Son Goku (Dragon Ball): A Saiyan from Planet Vegeta.
  • Cure Cosmo/Yuni (Star Twinkle PreCure): A shapeshifting catgirl from Planet Rainbow.
  • Zim (Invader Zim): An Irken invader sent to conquer Earth.
  • Upgrade (Ben 10): A Galvanic Mechamorph from Galvan B.
  • Atomix (Ben 10): An alien from an unknown planet who can create nuclear energy.

Comics 🔗

This section details humanoid aliens from comic books. Notable entries include:

  • Annihilus (Fantastic Four): A villain from the Marvel Universe. Created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby.
  • Cosmo (Cosmo the Merry Martian): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Bob White.
  • Darna (Darna): An extraterrestrial warrior who manifests in a human girl. Created by Mars Ravelo and Nestor Redondo.
  • Khâny (Yoko Tsuno): An alien from the planet Vinea. Created by Roger Leloup.
  • Plunk (Plunk): An alien from the planet Smurk. Created by Luc Cromheecke and Laurent Letzer.
  • The Scrameustache (Scrameustache): An alien with a cat-like face. Created by Roland Goossens (Gos).
  • Mr. Skygack (Mr. Skygack, from Mars): A Martian studying human behavior. Created by A.D. Condo.
  • Superman/Clark Kent (Action Comics #1): An alien from Krypton with superhuman powers. Created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster.
  • Xal-Kor (Xal-Kor the Human Cat): An alien from Felis who can transform between cat, hybrid, and human forms. Created by Grass Green.
  • Zook (Zook): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Jack Miller and Joe Certa.

Film 🔗

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in movies. Key examples include:

  • E.T. (E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial): An alien who befriends a human boy.
  • Various (Marvel Cinematic Universe): Includes Asgardians, members of the Guardians of the Galaxy, and Eternals.
  • Klaatu (The Day the Earth Stood Still): An alien who delivers a peaceful message to Earth.
  • Various (Star Wars): Includes Chewbacca, Yoda, Darth Maul, and Ahsoka Tano.
  • Zaphod Beeblebrox (The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy): An alien from near Betelgeuse.
  • Mork (Mork and Mindy): An alien from Ork who studies humanity on Earth.
  • The Alien Girl (Super Deluxe): An alien living on Earth, mingling with humans.

Literature 🔗

This section compiles humanoid aliens from literary works. Notable characters include:

  • The Little Prince (The Little Prince): A prince from an asteroid who visits Earth.
  • Curtis (One Door Away from Heaven): A shape-shifting alien on the run.
  • Ras Thavas (The Master Mind of Mars): A Martian mad scientist.
  • The Thing (Who Goes There?): A shapeshifting alien that takes a human form.

Television 🔗

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in television shows. Key characters include:

  • Adric (Doctor Who): A young native of Alzarius in E-Space.
  • ALF/Gordon Shumway (ALF): An alien from Melmac who crash lands on Earth.
  • Beldar, Prymaat, and Connie (Coneheads): An alien family from Remulak with conical heads.
  • Big Giant Head (3rd Rock from the Sun): The alien leader of the Solomons.
  • The Doctor (Doctor Who): An adventurer and scientist.
  • Fofão (Balão Mágico and TV Fofão): An extraterrestrial child character.
  • Gonzo (The Muppet Show): A puppet revealed to be of extraterrestrial origin.
  • Mork (Mork & Mindy): An alien from Ork who befriends a human woman.
  • Martin O’Hara (My Favorite Martian): A Martian anthropologist stranded on Earth.
  • Dick Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Harry Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Sally Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Tommy Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Spock (Star Trek): A Vulcan science officer on the Enterprise.
  • Ultraman (Ultraman): A race of aliens who protect the universe.
  • Ultronians (My Hero): A species from the planet Ultron with superpowers.

Video Games 🔗

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in video games. Key examples include:

  • Abe (Oddworld): The central character of the Oddworld series.
  • Artanis (StarCraft): A Protoss commander and protagonist.
  • Forerunner (Halo): Ancient Humanoid Aliens that created the Halo rings.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_humanoid_aliens

item.title: First contact (science fiction)
item.description:
First Contact (Science Fiction) 🔗

First contact is a recurring theme in science fiction, exploring the initial meeting between humans and extraterrestrial life or any sentient species from different planets or natural satellites. It draws parallels with the anthropological concept of first contact.

History 🔗

The concept dates back to the 2nd century AD with Lucian of Samosata’s A True Story. Voltaire’s Le Micromégas (1752) features an alien from Sirius visiting Earth and engaging in philosophical discussions with humans. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds is traditionally credited with popularizing the trope of conflict between humans and alien intelligent species, although earlier examples exist, such as Les Xipéhuz.

The 1950s saw a surge in first contact stories in the United States, often reflecting Cold War anxieties about nuclear holocaust or communist invasion. Films like The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) began to portray first contact as potentially beneficial, while Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956) reflected fears of communist infiltration.

Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End depicts both positive and negative consequences of first contact, while Stanisław Lem’s Solaris explores the futility of communication with extraterrestrial intelligence.

The Star Trek franchise introduced the Prime Directive, a non-interference regulation, which has since become a common trope in science fiction.

Later works include Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Carl Sagan’s Contact (1985), and novels like The Sparrow (1996) and The Three-Body Problem (2006). Films like Arrival (2016) focus on the linguistic challenges of first contact. Project Hail Mary (2021) depicts an unintended first contact scenario.

Types and Themes 🔗

First contact stories vary widely in their methods of contact and the nature of the subsequent interaction. These variations include positive vs. negative outcomes, physical meetings vs. message interception, and more.

Alien Invasion 🔗

Alien invasion is a common early trope, popularized by The War of the Worlds. During the Cold War, these stories often reflected American anxieties about the Soviet Union, with infiltration narratives being a variation on the theme.

Alien Artifacts 🔗

Bracewell probes, hypothesized by Ronald N. Bracewell, are extraterrestrial artifacts that allow real-time communication. Big Dumb Objects, such as megastructures like ringworlds, are a common variation. 2001: A Space Odyssey features mysterious black Monoliths that enhance technological progress. Stories also involve finding alien spacecraft, such as in Rendezvous with Rama.

Communication with Alien Intelligence 🔗

Many stories deal with the challenges of communication. Stanisław Lem’s works often portray mutual understanding between humans and aliens as impossible, criticizing the idea of cognitive universality.

Message from Space 🔗

First contact may occur through the detection of an extraterrestrial signal or technosignature. The search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) began with the advent of radio.

Alien Languages 🔗

Languages are a common form of communication with aliens, and many stories explore language issues. While space operas often use universal translators, hard science fiction typically depicts the difficulties of communicating with aliens, which can lead to misunderstandings and even war.

Ethics of First Contact 🔗

Many writers have considered how humans should treat aliens upon first contact. The Prime Directive of Star Trek is a notable example of non-interference. In Soviet science fiction, “progressors” worked clandestinely to improve less advanced civilizations.

Notable Examples 🔗

The Day the Earth Stood Still 🔗

Based on the short story “Farewell to the Master,” The Day the Earth Stood Still depicts the arrival of Klaatu and Gort in Washington, D.C. Humanity’s hostile response to first contact is used as an allegory for the Second Red Scare.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind 🔗

This 1977 film by Steven Spielberg tells the story of Roy Neary, whose life changes after an encounter with a UFO. The film was deemed “culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant” by the Library of Congress.

Contact 🔗

Carl Sagan’s 1985 novel, later adapted into a film, depicts the reception of a radio signal from Vega and the construction of a Machine based on the message’s specifications.

Star Trek 🔗

First contact is central to Starfleet operations in the Star Trek franchise. The Prime Directive is a foundational regulation, though it is frequently violated.

Star Trek: The Original Series 🔗

The original pilot episode features the Talosians. The Prime Directive was introduced in “The Return of the Archons” to prevent negative consequences from contact with technologically inferior societies.

Star Trek: The Next Generation 🔗

The pilot episode, “Encounter at Farpoint,” depicts first contact with the Q Continuum. Episodes like “Who Watches the Watchers” and “First Contact” center on the Prime Directive.

Star Trek: First Contact 🔗

This 1996 film portrays first contact between humans and Vulcans, leading to the formation of the United Federation of Planets.

The War of the Worlds 🔗

H.G. Wells’ novel details a conflict between humankind and Martians. It has been adapted into numerous films, radio dramas, and other media. The 1938 radio drama, directed by Orson Welles, reportedly caused panic among listeners.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_contact_(science_fiction)

item.title: Travis Walton incident
item.description:
The Travis Walton Incident 🔗

The Travis Walton incident is an alleged alien abduction that occurred on November 5, 1975, involving American forestry worker Travis Walton in the Apache–Sitgreaves National Forests near Heber, Arizona. The incident is widely considered a hoax.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the alleged abduction, noting that in the early 1970s, the National Enquirer tabloid offered a substantial prize for proof of extraterrestrial visitors, which may have motivated the hoax.

Travis Walton and the Turkey Springs forestry job 🔗

This section details the circumstances surrounding Travis Walton’s employment and the forestry contract. Key points include:

  • Location: The forestry job was located in Turkey Springs, about 12 miles south of Heber, Arizona. The crew lived in Snowflake, 30 miles away.
  • People: Travis Walton, his brother Duane, and crew chief Michael H. Rogers are central figures.
  • Financial Motive: Rogers’s forestry contract was behind schedule, potentially leading to financial penalties. The section notes that Walton had a prior criminal record.
  • Contract Details: The Turkey Springs job involved thinning 1,277 acres by August 1975, later extended to November 10. Failure to complete the job could result in a $2,500 penalty.

Barney Hill and NBC’s The UFO Incident 🔗

This section highlights the potential influence of the 1975 NBC television movie The UFO Incident, which dramatized the alleged abduction of Barney and Betty Hill. It suggests that the film may have inspired Walton and Rogers to fabricate their own abduction story. Skeptics and psychologists are quoted arguing that the film could have motivated someone to claim an abduction for attention. It also mentions that Travis Walton told his mother not to worry if he were ever abducted by aliens because he would return safe and sound.

Incident 🔗

This section outlines the events of November 5, 1975, when Michael H. Rogers reported Travis Walton missing. The crew claimed they saw a lit object near the roadway, Walton approached it, and was struck by a light. The crew drove away in fear and returned to find Walton and the object gone. The police were notified, and a search was initiated. Deputy Kenneth Coplan noted the calm reaction of Walton’s mother to the news of his disappearance.

Missing person investigation 🔗

This section details the search efforts and initial investigation following Walton’s disappearance. Key points include:

  • Search Party: A search party of nearly 50 people scoured the Turkey Springs area without success.
  • Family’s Reaction: Law enforcement were surprised by the calm reaction of Travis’s mother, who believed he was no longer on Earth.
  • UFO Interest: It was revealed that Travis, Duane, and their mother were interested in UFOs.
  • Polygraph Tests: Rogers and the crew underwent polygraph examinations to determine if they had harmed Walton. Five were deemed truthful, while one was inconclusive.
  • Act of God Clause: Rogers discussed the Forestry contract and the potential for an “Act of God” clause to excuse the delay.

Walton returns 🔗

This section describes Walton’s reappearance and subsequent events. Key points include:

  • Return: Walton called his sister’s home from a payphone in Heber, Arizona, on November 12, shortly after midnight.
  • Deputy Glen Flake: Deputy Flake witnessed Duane Walton transferring fuel from one car to another after having forgotten to purchase gas before local stations closed. Flake did not reveal that they knew Travis had returned home, and Duane did not tell the deputy that Travis had been found.
  • Medical Attention: Duane sought medical attention for Travis, consulting with a hypnotherapist and later two medical doctors who were also amateur UFO investigators.
  • Sheriff Gillespie: Sheriff Gillespie insisted on interviewing Travis, but Duane and Travis demanded that the interview not be recorded.
  • National Enquirer: The National Enquirer provided a suite at the Sheraton Inn in Scottsdale in exchange for exclusive access to Walton and his story.
  • Polygraph Test: Travis skipped a polygraph interview with police, but was later interviewed by Jack McCarthy a free-lance polygraph examiner arranged by a UFO group and the Enquirer. McCarthy concluded that Travis was engaged in a “gross deception”.
  • Television Interview: Walton appeared on Phoenix television, claiming he lost consciousness and awoke in a hospital-like room with short, bald creatures.

Publicity and popular culture 🔗

This section covers the media attention and cultural impact of the Walton incident. Key points include:

  • National Enquirer Prize: The National Enquirer awarded Walton and his co-workers a $5,000 prize for “best UFO case of the year.”
  • Skepticism: Skeptics, including Philip J. Klass, viewed the story as a hoax for financial gain.
  • Book and Film: Walton wrote The Walton Experience in 1978, which was adapted into the 1993 film Fire in the Sky.
  • Media Appearances: Walton has appeared at UFO conventions and on television, including The Moment of Truth and the Joe Rogan Experience podcast.

Rogers-Walton dispute of 2021 🔗

This section details a public dispute between Mike Rogers and Travis Walton in 2021. Rogers initially recanted his status as a witness to the abduction, claiming it was a hoax, but later reconciled with Walton and retracted his confession.

Modern views 🔗

This section presents contemporary perspectives on the Walton incident.

Waltons as UFO buffs and pranksters 🔗

This section highlights the Walton family’s interest in UFOs and their reputation for pranks. It suggests that the incident may have been planned by Travis Walton and Mike Rogers. Crew member Steve Pierce expressed suspicion that the incident had been a hoax.

National Enquirer misrepresented polygraph results 🔗

This section notes that the National Enquirer publicized the opinion of a private polygraph examiner who reported the witnesses as being truthful, but omitted all mention of Walton’s prior polygraph examiner who concluded Walton was being “grossly deceptive”.

Contrast with alien abduction syndrome 🔗

This section contrasts Walton’s account with typical alien abduction narratives, noting that Walton didn’t report paralysis, recovered memories, or other common elements.

Possible role of fire lookout tower 🔗

This section presents Robert Sheaffer’s hypothesis that Rogers and the Waltons used a nearby fire lookout tower to create the illusion of a UFO. Sheaffer suggests that Travis walked towards the tower, which was brightly lit, and an accomplice illuminated him with a spotlight.

See also 🔗

This section lists related topics, including lists of reported UFO sightings and solved missing person cases.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travis_Walton_UFO_incident

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts 🔗

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected the development of cultures, technologies, religions, and even human biology. A common idea is that deities in many religions were actually extraterrestrials, and their advanced technologies were seen as divine powers by early humans.

This idea is rejected by academics and archaeologists, who consider it pseudoarchaeology and unscientific. Claims are often based on distorted or fabricated evidence. Some critics argue that ancient astronaut theories have racist implications, diminishing the achievements of indigenous cultures.

Notable proponents in the late 20th century include Robert Charroux, Jacques Bergier, Jean Sendy, Erich von Däniken, Alexander Kazantsev, Zecharia Sitchin, Robert K. G. Temple, Giorgio A. Tsoukalos, David Hatcher Childress, Peter Kolosimo, and Mauro Biglino.

Overview 🔗

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI.

Believers often claim that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence that landed on Earth in the past. They suggest that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these ancient alien visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Proponents also claim that extraterrestrials built or helped humans build structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island. Evidence is said to come from gaps in historical and archaeological records, as well as artifacts that are considered anachronistic and beyond the technical capabilities of ancient people. These “out-of-place artifacts” include artwork and legends reinterpreted to support extraterrestrial contact.

The idea is featured in fringe media, such as the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. The show mixes fact with fiction to promote theories of an alternate past, often incorporating white supremacist, nativist, imperialist, settler-colonial, and Christian Identity beliefs. Proponents portray themselves as an oppressed minority of academics challenging mainstream archaeology, despite lacking credentials.

Like past archaeological endeavors, the focus is on monumental structures, suggesting that indigenous people could not have built them without alien help. However, some indigenous voices argue that ancient alien theory supports their stories of extraterrestrial origins.

A common theme is the portrayal of aliens as light-skinned or Aryan, as claimed by Erich von Däniken. Some proponents are associated with white supremacism.

Mainstream archaeologists have largely ignored these claims, while popular science explainers and skeptics have criticized them. Carl Sagan noted that cases of apparent interest have reasonable alternative explanations, misreporting, or are hoaxes and distortions.

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents 🔗

Paleocontact narratives appeared in early science fiction of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It gained popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and Erich von Däniken’s works. Critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von Däniken’s claims. By the early 1980s, support dwindled.

Shklovskii and Sagan 🔗

Carl Sagan co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe (1966) with Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky. In Broca’s Brain (1979), Sagan expressed disapproval of writers like von Däniken who treated speculations as valid evidence of extraterrestrial contact. Sagan noted that many legends, artifacts, and out-of-place artifacts cited in support of ancient astronaut hypotheses could be explained with conventional hypotheses. He reiterated that extraterrestrial visits were possible but unproven and improbable.

Erich von Däniken 🔗

Erich von Däniken became a leading proponent in the late 1960s and early 1970s with his book Chariots of the Gods? (1968) and its sequels.

Von Däniken argued that certain artifacts required more advanced technology than was available to ancient cultures. He claimed that these artifacts were constructed by extraterrestrial visitors or humans who learned from them. Examples include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries.

He wrote that ancient art and iconography depict air and space vehicles, intelligent non-human creatures, ancient astronauts, and advanced technology. He also stated that geographically separated cultures share artistic themes, implying a common origin. One example is his interpretation of the sarcophagus lid from the tomb of Pacal the Great in Palenque, which he saw as a seated astronaut, while Maya texts identify it as a portrait of the ruler with the World Tree.

Von Däniken interpreted the origins of many religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, whose technology was seen as supernatural. He stated that religious traditions contain references to alien visitors, such as Ezekiel’s revelation, which he interpreted as a landing spacecraft.

His hypotheses became popularized in the U.S. through the NBC-TV documentary In Search of Ancient Astronauts and the film Chariots of the Gods.

Critics argue that von Däniken misrepresented data, made unfounded claims, and failed to validate his core claims. Christian creationists also criticized his work.

Regarding the Nazca Lines, von Däniken stated that they resembled an airfield when seen from the air. Kenneth L. Feder argues that readers seeing the Nazca Lines in a book about aliens would be more likely to associate them with extraterrestrial origins.

In 1970, von Däniken admitted that the Nazca markings could have been laid out using a system of coordinates.

Zecharia Sitchin 🔗

Zecharia Sitchin’s The Earth Chronicles series revolves around his interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesized that the gods of Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet Nibiru, which the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet” associated with the god Marduk. According to Sitchin, Nibiru orbits the Sun on a 3,600-year elongated orbit. Modern astronomy has found no evidence to support these ideas.

Sitchin argued that Sumerian texts tell the story of 50 Anunnaki from Nibiru who came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They genetically engineered laborers, creating Homo sapiens sapiens: the “Adapa” or Adam of later mythology. Sitchin contended that the Anunnaki were active in human affairs until their culture was destroyed by global catastrophes caused by the end of the last ice age.

His work has not received mainstream scholarly support and has been criticized by professionals. Semitic languages scholar Michael S. Heiser says that many of Sitchin’s translations are inconsistent with Mesopotamian cuneiform dictionaries.

Alan F. Alford, author of Gods of the New Millennium, initially adhered to Sitchin’s hypotheses but later found fault, stating that the gods personified the falling sky and that the descent of the gods was a poetic rendition of the cataclysm myth.

Robert Temple 🔗

Robert K. G. Temple’s 1976 book, The Sirius Mystery, argues that the Dogon people of northwestern Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He cites advanced astronomical knowledge, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations. His work draws on the studies of cultural anthropologists Marcel Griaule and Germaine Dieterlen.

His conclusions have been criticized by scientists, who point out discrepancies and suggest that the Dogon may have received their astronomical information recently from European sources.

UFO Religions 🔗

Various new religious movements, including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, Raëlism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate, believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many see ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens. Psychologists have found that UFO religions have similarities suggesting that members associate enchantment with science fiction memes.

Claims of Proponents 🔗

The scientific consensus is that the ancient astronaut hypothesis is not impossible, but unjustified and unnecessary. The “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without invoking ancient astronauts. Since ancient astronauts are unnecessary, Occam’s razor should be applied and the hypothesis rejected.

Ancient Religious Texts 🔗

Proponents cite ancient mythologies, suggesting that creation myths of gods descending from the heavens to create or instruct humanity are representations of alien visitors. They draw an analogy to cargo cults, where isolated cultures believed Western ships and cargo were sent from the gods.

The ancient Sumerian myth of Enûma Eliš says humankind was created to serve gods called the “Annunaki.” Proponents believe that the Annunaki were aliens who came to Earth to mine gold and created the human race as slaves.

Ramayana 🔗

In Hindu mythology, the gods and their avatars travel in flying vehicles called Vimana. The Ramayana mentions these flying objects, used by the Lankan king Ravana from Sri Lanka.

Examples from the Ramayana include descriptions of the Pushpak chariot, a

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts

item.title: Nazi UFOs
item.description:
Conspiracy theories alleging connections between UFOs and Nazi Germany 🔗

This article explores the conspiracy theories linking UFOs to Nazi Germany, asserting that the Nazis attempted to develop advanced aircraft and spacecraft before and during World War II. It further claims that these craft survived in secret underground bases in Antarctica, South America, or the United States, along with their creators.

Early UFOs as possible Nazi technology 🔗

This section discusses how unusual aerial sightings during and after World War II were initially attributed to novel Nazi technology. During the Cold War, speculation arose that the Soviets might be deploying captured or reverse-engineered Nazi technology.

Foo fighters 🔗

During World War II, Allied and Axis personnel witnessed unusual aerial phenomena called “foo fighters.” While some reports were dismissed as misperceptions, others were taken seriously, leading scientists like Luis Alvarez to investigate. Allied intelligence suspected some foo fighters were advanced German aircraft or weapons, given Germany’s technological innovations like V-1 and V-2 missiles and the Me 262 jet fighter.

Ghost rockets 🔗

In 1946, rocket- or missile-shaped UFOs, known as “ghost rockets,” were sighted primarily in Sweden and nearby countries. Finnish observers made the first reports in February 1946. Investigations suggested some sightings were meteors, but others displayed characteristics inconsistent with meteors, such as maneuverability. It was initially believed that the ghost rockets originated from the former German rocket facility at Peenemünde and were Soviet tests of captured German missiles.

Flying discs 🔗

Following Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting of crescent-shaped objects, speculation about German technology resurfaced. Project Sign personnel noted similarities between the Horten brothers’ flying wing designs and some UFO reports. Edward J. Ruppelt, the first head of Project Blue Book, noted that the Germans had several radical aircraft and guided missiles under development at the end of WWII.

The earliest media assertion of German flying saucers appeared in the Italian newspaper Il Giornale d’Italia in 1950. Professor Giuseppe Belluzzo claimed that flying discs were designed and studied in Germany and Italy as early as 1942.

In the same month, German technician Rudolf Schriever claimed to Der Spiegel that he designed a craft powered by rotating turbine blades while working at BMW’s Prague works until April 1945. He said his designs were stolen, and he believed Czech agents built his craft for a foreign power.

In 1953, German engineer Georg Klein claimed that designs similar to Avro Canada’s Avrocar had been developed during the Nazi era. Klein identified two types of supposed German flying disks: one developed by Richard Miethe in Breslau and another developed by Rudolf Schriever and Klaus Habermohl in Prague.

Aeronautical engineer Roy Fedden stated in 1945 that the only craft that could approach the capabilities attributed to flying saucers were those being designed by the Germans towards the end of the war.

Nazi UFO conspiracy theories 🔗

By the 1960s, fringe authors began circulating tales of Nazi UFOs tied to the occult or aliens. These theories reference various potential code-names or sub-classifications of Nazi UFO craft.
