German UFO literature often aligns with documented history regarding Nazi Germany’s claim to New Swabia in Antarctica and its research into advanced propulsion technology.

The Morning of the Magicians 🔗

Le Matin des Magiciens, a 1960 book by Louis Pauwels and Jacques Bergier, made claims about the Vril Society of Berlin. Later writers, including Jan van Helsing, Norbert-Jürgen Ratthofer, and Vladimir Terziski, connected the Vril Society with UFOs, claiming the society contacted an alien race and developed spacecraft to reach them. They allege that the Vril Society, in partnership with the Thule Society and the Nazi Party, developed flying disc prototypes and retreated to a base in Antarctica after the Nazi defeat.

The works of Ernst Zündel 🔗

Ernst Zündel’s Samisdat Publishers claimed that flying saucers were Nazi secret weapons launched from an underground base in Antarctica, aiming to conquer Earth and other planets. Zündel also sold seats on an exploration team to locate the polar entrance to the hollow earth.

Miguel Serrano’s book 🔗

In 1978, Miguel Serrano published El Cordón Dorado: Hitlerismo Esotérico, claiming that Adolf Hitler was an Avatar of Vishnu communing with Hyperborean gods in an underground Antarctic base in New Swabia. Serrano predicted that Hitler would lead a fleet of UFOs from the base to establish the Fourth Reich.

Die Glocke 🔗

Die Glocke (“The Bell”) was a purported top-secret Nazi scientific technological device or Wunderwaffe. First described by Igor Witkowski in Prawda o Wunderwaffe (2000) and popularized by Nick Cook, it was associated with Nazi occultism, antigravity, and free energy suppression research. Claims about Die Glocke have been criticized as fictional and a hoax.

In popular culture 🔗

This section lists examples of Nazi UFOs appearing in popular culture, including:

  • Robert A. Heinlein’s Rocket Ship Galileo (1947) featuring a Nazi Moon base.
  • The video game Medal of Honor: Frontline (2002) featuring a Nazi UFO.
  • The movie Iron Sky (2012) featuring a Nazi base on the moon launching an assault on Earth with flying saucers.
  • Revell releasing a scale model kit of a Nazi flying saucer called “Haunebu II” (2018), which was later removed from production due to historical inaccuracies.
  • The video game Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus (2017) featuring “Haunebu-V” craft manufactured in Nazi-controlled Roswell, New Mexico.
  • The Commando Comic Flight of Fancy (2017) featuring the Schriever Flugkreisel.
  • The second season finale of 30 Coins (2023) mentioning Haunebu UFOs as copies of Nazca UFOs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazi_UFOs

item.title: List of alien races in Marvel Comics
item.description:
List of Alien Races in Marvel Comics 🔗

This document provides a comprehensive list of alien races that appear in Marvel Comics. It is organized alphabetically and includes both major and secondary races, along with their key characteristics and appearances.

Contents 🔗

This section simply lists the letters of the alphabet, serving as a quick index to find alien races by their starting letter.

Overview 🔗

This section establishes that the Marvel Comics universe contains a vast number of extraterrestrial races, most of which are humanoid.

Galactic Council 🔗

This section introduces the Galactic Council, an assembly of leaders from various alien empires. It was created to address universal matters.

Current members 🔗

This lists the current members of the Galactic Council, including representatives from the Kree/Skrull Alliance (Kl’rt/Paibok), Shi’ar Empire (Oracle-2/Izzy Kane), Utopian Kree (Noh-Varr), Earth/Nova Corps (Richard Rider), Spartax (Empress Victoria/Peter Quill), Rigellians (Mentacle), Kymellians (Nymbis Sternhoof), Wakanda (Riitho), Galactic Rim Collective (Zoralis Gupa/Orbis Stellaris), Badoon Sisterhood (Lani Ko Ako), Chitauri Empire (Peacebringer), and Zn’rx Empire (Empress Kuga).

Former members 🔗

This lists former members of the Galactic Council, including representatives from Asgard (Freyja), Brotherhood of the Badoon (Y-Gaaar), Kree Empire (Supreme Intelligence/Ronan the Accuser), Negative Zone (Annihilus), Axi-Tun (Alberik), Shi’ar Empire (Majestor/Lilandra), Badoon (Manat), Brood (Brood Queen), Inhuman Royal Family (Gorgon/Medusa/Crystal/Karnak), Ruul/Kree Empire (Kronaster Sintariis), Kree/Skrull Alliance (Captain Val-Lorr), Krylorians (Bartos), Kymellians (Fayrelyte Strongheart), Negative Zone (Blastaar), Planet X (Groot), Rigellians (Nelet Pa), Skrull Empire (Kreddik), Sneepers (Dibdeb), Stonians (Basaltar), Wobbow (Wibbow), Spartax (J’son), Zn’rx (Emperor Stote), and Chitauri (Peacemaker).

In other media 🔗

This section notes the Galactic Council’s appearance in the Guardians of the Galaxy animated series, with members including J’son, Thor, Irani Rael, the Rigellian Grand Commissioner, and the Supreme Intelligence.

Major races 🔗

This section introduces alien races that have had significant presence in Marvel Comics publications, including major crossovers and storylines.

Badoon 🔗

The Badoon are reptilian aliens known for strict gender segregation, resulting in the Brotherhood of Badoon (ruled by a “Brother Royal”) and the Sisterhood of Badoon (ruled by a Queen). They first appeared in Silver Surfer #2.

Beyonders 🔗

The Beyonders are enigmatic, virtually omnipotent entities powerful enough to collect planets. They cannot leave their dimension and operate through agents. The Beyonder is the most notable member. They were first mentioned in Marvel Two-in-One #63.

Brood 🔗

The Brood are a race of insectoid, parasitic, extraterrestrial beings. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men #155.

Celestials 🔗

The Celestials have existed since near the birth of the universe. They first appeared in The Eternals #1.

Chitauri 🔗

The Chitauri are aliens similar to the Skrulls in the Ultimate Marvel universe. They have since been established in the main Marvel Universe. They first appeared in The Ultimates #8.

Cotati 🔗

The Cotati are a race of highly intelligent, telepathic plants originating on Hala, the same planet as the Kree. They first appeared in The Avengers #133.

Dire Wraiths 🔗

The Dire Wraiths are an evolutionary offshoot of the Skrulls from the Andromeda Galaxy. Like the Skrulls, they are shapeshifters. They first appeared in Rom the Spaceknight #1.

Kree 🔗

The Kree are a scientifically and technologically advanced militaristic alien race native to the planet Hala. They were the rivals of the Skrulls. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #65.

Phalanx 🔗

The Phalanx are a cybernetic species that form a hive-mind. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men #305.

Shi’ar 🔗

The Shi’ar are alien humanoids of avian descent residing in the Shi’ar Empire. Their empire is a vast collection of alien species, cultures, and worlds. They first appeared in X-Men #97.

Skrulls 🔗

The Skrulls are a race of shapeshifting aliens originating from the planet Skrullos. They were the rivals of the Kree. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #2.

Symbiotes 🔗

The Symbiotes are amorphous extraterrestrial parasites that envelop their hosts like costumes, creating a symbiotic bond. They are also known as the Klyntar. They first appeared in Secret Wars #8.

Watchers 🔗

The Watchers are the first humanoid race created in the Marvel Universe. They observe and compile knowledge on all aspects of the universe but have vowed not to interfere. Uatu is the most known Watcher. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #13.

Secondary races 🔗

This section lists a multitude of other extraterrestrial races that have appeared in Marvel Comics, though not as prominently as the major races.

A 🔗

This section lists alien races starting with the letter “A”.

A’askvarii 🔗

The A’askvarii are a green-skinned humanoid race with octopus traits from the oceanic planet O’erlanii. They first appeared in Black Goliath.

A-Chiltarians 🔗

The A-Chiltarians are a purple-grey furred humanoid race with many eyes from the marshy planet A-Chiltar III. Kraglin is an A-Chiltarian. They first appeared in Tales to Astonish.

Aakon 🔗

The Aakon are a yellow-skinned, dark-haired humanoid race and enemies of the Kree. They are allied with the Shadow Consortium. They first appeared in Captain Marvel.

Acanti 🔗

The Acanti are a race of space creatures that resemble whales. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men.

Achernonians 🔗

The Achernonians are a purple-skinned humanoid race from the rocky planet Achernon. They are depicted as superstitious and have a dictatorial government. Some can become immaterial. They first appeared in Thor.

Aedians 🔗

The Aedians are thin humanoid bipeds with elongated craniums and no noses. They possess telepathic and empathic powers and can project their astral selves. They first appeared in Silver Surfer.

Agullo 🔗

The Agullo are an alien race that was diminished from over 60,000,000 to a few thousands after Thanos came to their planet Ahl-Agullo.

Alpha Centaurians 🔗

The Alpha Centaurians are a humanoid race with grey scales adapted for underwater living from the planet Arima. They have a feudal government and are capable of near-lightspeed travel. They first appeared in Sub-Mariner.

Amebids 🔗

The Amebids are a race of jellyfish-like aliens that come from the planet Sakaar.

Annunaki 🔗

The Annunaki are an alien race that helped Silver Surfer gather and protect some of Earth’s most extraordinary gifted children.

Archeopians 🔗

The Archeopians are from the planet Archeopia. Most of the race was killed when the incubator cube of Galactus was opened and he consumed Archeopia.

Arcturans 🔗

The Arcturans are a pink-white skinned humanoid race from Arcturus IV. A significant portion of their population are mutants. Starhawk and Aleta are Arcturans. They first appeared in Fear.

Aris 🔗

The Aris are an alien race that comes from the planet Ariston.

Arthrosians 🔗

The Arthrosians are a race of insectoids that come from the planet Anthros in the Negative Zone. Annihilus is an Arthrosian.

Aspirants 🔗

The Aspirants are a race of celestial beings that were the result of the First Firmament’s loneliness.

Astrans 🔗

The Astrans are a yellow-skinned humanoid race with flat feet from the planet Astra. They can control metal and are mostly priests or artists. They first appeared in The Incredible Hulk.

Astrans in other media 🔗

The Astrans appear in Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.

Ataraxians 🔗

The Ataraxians are a race of aliens from the planet Ataraxia in the Negative Zone.

Autocrons 🔗

The Autocrons are a blue-black skinned humanoid race with iron-based bodies from the planet Cron. They possess superhuman strength and durability and have an imperialistic, militaristic culture ruled by a world-computer

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_alien_races_in_Marvel_Comics

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

This article discusses extraterrestrials as they are portrayed in works of fiction, distinguishing them from alleged real-life encounters. It includes a link to a separate article listing alleged extraterrestrial beings. A banner at the top indicates that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and needs more citations.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction, starting from antiquity and progressing through modern times.

Antiquity 🔗

This subsection covers early depictions of extraterrestrials, beginning with Lucian’s 2nd-century satire True History, where the protagonist visits the Moon and finds it inhabited by warring factions. It emphasizes how early concepts of extraterrestrials were tied to the development of astronomy and the understanding of celestial objects as physical entities. Early depictions often portrayed aliens as human-like, as exemplified by Voltaire’s Micromégas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac.

Early 20th Century 🔗

This section discusses the impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species on alien depictions, leading to the creation of non-humanoid aliens in fiction. Camille Flammarion’s works are mentioned as early examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. The section also highlights H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds and The First Men in the Moon as influential works that explored the implications of evolution and alien civilizations. The rise of pulp magazines and their role in popularizing science fiction with various alien tropes are also discussed, including the common use of Martians, Venusians, and other Solar System inhabitants. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is noted for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times 🔗

This section covers the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. It mentions The Eternaut by Héctor Germán Oesterheld, an Argentine work that critiques imperialism and colonialism through an alien invasion of Buenos Aires. The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as a pivotal event that popularized the “grey alien” archetype. The influence of TV and films, particularly Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien, is highlighted, noting the trend towards human-like aliens due to budgetary constraints. The section concludes by mentioning the impact of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on creating more diverse and bizarre alien lifeforms.

Types 🔗

This section categorizes the various ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction. It discusses differences in intelligence levels, biological forms (humanoid, Earth-species-like, or bizarre), and attitudes towards humanity (hostile, friendly, or indifferent). It also mentions that some extraterrestrials in fiction originate from unexplored areas of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

See Also 🔗

This section provides a list of related Wikipedia articles, including:

  • Parasites in fiction
  • List of fictional extraterrestrials
  • List of films featuring extraterrestrials
  • List of humanoid aliens
  • Mars in fiction
  • First contact (science fiction)

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, journal articles, and online resources.

Bibliography 🔗

This section lists additional books related to the topic of extraterrestrials in fiction.

Further Reading 🔗

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about the topic, including books and articles.

External Links 🔗

This section contains a link to an external website with additional information on the use of aliens as metaphors in fiction.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life_in_popular_culture

item.title: Alien invasion
item.description:
Alien Invasion 🔗

Alien invasion, also known as space invasion, is a prevalent theme in science fiction stories and films. It involves extraterrestrial lifeforms invading Earth with various motives, such as exterminating or enslaving humanity, harvesting humans for food, stealing resources, or destroying the planet. This theme is a subgenre of invasion literature, popularized by H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds, and is a type of first contact science fiction. Experts consider an actual alien invasion unlikely due to the immense costs involved.

Origins 🔗

This section discusses the origins of the alien invasion theme in fiction. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) is considered the seminal alien invasion story, establishing themes like first contact and interplanetary war. However, earlier stories exist, such as Robert Potter’s The Germ Growers (1892), which features a covert alien invasion. The section also mentions Wells’ proposed guerrilla war scenario in The War of the Worlds. Garrett P. Serviss’ Edison’s Conquest of Mars, an unauthorized sequel to The War of the Worlds, depicts Thomas Edison leading a counterattack on Mars. The reprinting of The War of the Worlds in the United States in 1927 coincided with the Golden Age of Science Fiction. John W. Campbell and other science fiction writers, including Isaac Asimov, Arthur C. Clarke, Clifford D. Simak, and Robert A. Heinlein, further developed the theme.

Variations 🔗

This section explores different variations of the alien invasion theme.

Alien Infiltration 🔗

This variation involves invaders taking human form and infiltrating society, even taking control of command positions. Their goal may be to take over the world or prepare for a full-scale invasion. This theme reflects Cold War fears of communist infiltration. The Reptilian conspiracy theory is mentioned as a real-world belief in covert alien infiltration.

Beneficial Alien Invasion 🔗

This variation presents aliens colonizing Earth to “civilize” humanity or secretly aiding humans to prevent self-destruction. Henry Slesar’s The Delegate from Venus is mentioned. Examples include Klaatu and Gort in The Day the Earth Stood Still, Gene Roddenberry’s The Questor Tapes and Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth”, Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Crest of the Stars, the film Arrival, and David Brin’s Uplift Universe series.

Invasion by Humans 🔗

This variation reverses the roles, with humans invading or attacking extraterrestrial lifeforms. Examples include the short story Sentry, the video game Phantasy Star II, The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury, the Imperium of Man in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Invaders from Earth by Robert Silverberg, Ender’s Game by Orson Scott Card, and the movies Battle for Terra, Planet 51, and Avatar.

Feasibility 🔗

This section discusses the feasibility of an actual alien invasion. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute believes it’s unlikely due to resource availability and the likelihood of initial contact being through robots. David Morrison of NASA-Ames Research Center suggests first contact would be via radio communication.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including interplanetary contamination, potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact, space colonization, UFO religion, The Kraken Wakes, list of films featuring space stations, and the Wow! signal.

References 🔗

This section lists the references used in the article, providing sources for the information presented.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_invasion

item.title: Mutual UFO Network
item.description:
Mutual UFO Network 🔗

The Mutual UFO Network (MUFON) is a US-based non-profit organization dedicated to the scientific study of UFOs. Founded in 1969, it has grown to include over 4,000 members worldwide, with chapters in over 43 countries and all 50 US states. MUFON aims to investigate UFO sightings and provide information to the public.

History 🔗

MUFON was originally established as the Midwest UFO Network on May 31, 1969, in Quincy, Illinois, by Allen R. Utke, Walter H. Andrus, Jr., John F. Schuessler, and others. It was renamed the Mutual UFO Network in 1973 due to its expansion. In July 2020, Executive Director Jan Harzan was arrested on charges of soliciting sex from a minor and was subsequently removed from his position.

Operation 🔗

Headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, MUFON has chapters throughout the U.S. and internationally. It hosts an annual international symposium and publishes the monthly MUFON UFO Journal. In 2015, MUFON founded Mutual UFO Network University, an unaccredited online institution for training UFO investigators. The organization has over 500 field investigators who investigate potential physical evidence of extraterrestrial craft.

Criticism 🔗

Pseudoscience 🔗

MUFON has faced criticism for its focus on pseudoscience, including topics like alien abduction, conspiracy theories, and human-ET hybrids. Critics argue that MUFON’s investigations lack scientific rigor and that its researchers are often not scientists.

Officers and donors with far-right viewpoints 🔗

In 2018, Newsweek reported on anti-immigrant, anti-trans, and anti-Muslim sentiments among MUFON officials and donors, including J. Z. Knight and John Ventre. This led to resignations from members like Chris Cogswell and James Clarkson. In 2020, Vice reported that Ken Pfeifer, head of MUFON’s Rhode Island chapter, posted racist content on Facebook.

Popular culture 🔗

MUFON has been mentioned in various television shows and news articles, including:

Television 🔗

  • UFOs Over Earth (2008)
  • UFO Hunters (2008)
  • The X-Files
  • Ancient Aliens
  • Hangar 1: The UFO Files
  • 9-1-1: Lone Star (Season 3, Episode 6 “The ATX-Files”)

News 🔗

  • The New York Times article “People Are Seeing U.F.O.s Everywhere, and This Book Proves It”
  • Forbes article “MUFON, America’s UFO Experts, Discuss Roswell And Possible Cover-Ups”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MUFON

item.title: Mutual UFO Network
item.description:
Mutual UFO Network 🔗

The Mutual UFO Network (MUFON) is a US-based non-profit organization dedicated to the scientific study of UFOs. Founded in 1969, it has grown to include over 4,000 members worldwide, with chapters and representatives in numerous countries and all 50 US states.

History 🔗

Originally established as the Midwest UFO Network in Quincy, Illinois, on May 31, 1969, by Allen R. Utke, Walter H. Andrus, Jr., and John F. Schuessler, among others. Many early members were associated with the SKYLOOK newsletter and the Aerial Phenomena Research Organization (APRO). The organization expanded and was renamed the Mutual UFO Network in 1973. In July 2020, Executive Director Jan Harzan was arrested on charges of soliciting sex from a minor and was subsequently removed from his position.

Operation 🔗

MUFON is headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, and has chapters in every U.S. state. It holds an annual international symposium and publishes the monthly MUFON UFO Journal. In 2015, MUFON founded Mutual UFO Network University, an unaccredited online institution that trains members to investigate UFO sightings. The network claims over 500 field investigators and specialized teams to investigate potential physical evidence of extraterrestrial craft. Volunteers are trained to interview witnesses, conduct research, and analyze evidence, requiring them to pass an exam and a background check. MUFON’s website features a newsroom and case management system.

Criticism 🔗

Pseudoscience 🔗

MUFON has faced criticism for its focus on pseudoscience. Critics argue that the organization’s conferences and publications delve into topics like alien abduction, conspiracy theories, human-ET hybrids, hypnotic regression, and repressed memories, which are considered unscientific. The qualifications of the amateur volunteers who examine UFO reports have also been questioned.

Officers and donors with far-right viewpoints 🔗

In April 2018, Newsweek reported evidence of anti-immigrant, anti-trans, and anti-Muslim sentiments among MUFON officials and donors, including J. Z. Knight and former MUFON State Director for Pennsylvania John Ventre. These individuals have publicly expressed racist and/or anti-Semitic views. This led to resignations from MUFON, including former Director of Research Chris Cogswell and former board member and Washington State Director James Clarkson. Erica Lukes, former MUFON State Director for Utah, described MUFON as unwilling to adequately address sexual harassment. In 2020, Vice magazine reported that Ken Pfeifer, head of MUFON’s Rhode Island chapter, posted racist memes and comments on Facebook.

Popular culture 🔗

MUFON has been mentioned in various television shows, including:

  • UFOs Over Earth (Discovery Channel)
  • UFO Hunters (History Channel)
  • The X-Files
  • Ancient Aliens (History Channel)
  • Hangar 1: The UFO Files
  • 9-1-1: Lone Star

It has also been mentioned in news articles in The New York Times and Forbes.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_UFO_Network

item.title: Aurora, Texas, UFO incident
item.description:
Aurora, Texas, UFO Incident 🔗

This article details the alleged UFO crash that reportedly occurred on April 17, 1897, near Aurora, Texas. Locals claimed a UFO crashed on a farm, resulting in the death of its pilot, an alien being. The pilot was purportedly buried in the Aurora Cemetery.

The Incident as Reported 🔗

This section recounts the details of the incident as reported in the Dallas Morning News article written by S.E. Haydon. The article describes how a UFO crashed into a windmill on Judge J.S. Proctor’s property. The pilot, described as “not of this world,” was speculated to be from Mars by an Army Signal Service officer named T.J. Weems. The pilot was buried with Christian rites in the Aurora Cemetery, which now has a Texas Historical Commission marker mentioning the incident. The wreckage was reportedly dumped into a well on the property. Mr. Brawley Oates, who later purchased the property, sealed the well after developing severe arthritis, which he attributed to contamination from the wreckage.

Hoax Theory 🔗

This section presents the theory that the Aurora incident was a hoax. It cites a 1980 Time magazine interview with Etta Pegues, an Aurora resident, who claimed that S.E. Haydon fabricated the story to revive the town’s economy after the railroad bypassed it. Pegues also claimed that Judge Proctor never had a windmill on his property, a statement that was later challenged. Paranormal researcher Jerry Drake challenged the finding that the well was designed for use with a windmill.

Investigations 🔗

This section outlines the various investigations into the Aurora incident, including reports by KDFW, UFO Files, and UFO Hunters.

KDFW Report 🔗

In 1998, KDFW aired a report featuring interviews with Jim Marrs and other locals who believed something crashed in Aurora. The report found no conclusive evidence of extraterrestrial life or technology.

UFO Files Investigation 🔗

The UFO Files episode, “Texas’ Roswell,” featured a 1973 investigation led by Bill Case of the Dallas Times Herald and MUFON. The investigation uncovered two new eyewitnesses: Mary Evans, who spoke of her parents’ visit to the crash site and the discovery of the alien body, and Charlie Stephens, who saw the airship trailing smoke. MUFON investigated the Aurora Cemetery and found a grave marker that appeared to depict a flying saucer. They requested permission to exhume the site but were denied. The marker later disappeared, and metal readings from the grave vanished. The report concluded that the evidence was inconclusive.

UFO Hunters Investigation 🔗

The UFO Hunters episode, “First Contact,” featured Tim Oates, grandson of Brawley Oates, allowing investigators to unseal the well on his property. Water samples showed high levels of aluminum, but the well contained no significant debris. The remains of a windmill base were found near the well site. Ground-penetrating radar revealed an unmarked grave in the cemetery near other 1890s graves. The condition of the grave was badly deteriorated, and the radar could not conclusively prove what type of remains existed. The landowner provided pieces of metal containing mostly aluminum and an unknown element.

In Popular Culture 🔗

This section notes the dramatization of the incident in the 1986 film The Aurora Encounter and its discussion in Ancient Aliens. It also mentions an independent short movie titled Aurora by Thomas Negovan and Aaron Shaps, which combines the incident with the Nazi conspiracy theory of Die Glocke. The Firesign Theatre’s comedy LP Everything You Know Is Wrong satirizes the incident.

See Also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including “List of reported UFO sightings” and “Mystery airship.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aurora,_Texas,_UFO_incident

item.title: Roswell incident
item.description:
UFO Legend Caused by 1947 Balloon Crash: Roswell Incident 🔗

The Roswell incident is a cornerstone of UFO lore, stemming from the recovery of debris near Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. Initially reported as a “flying disc” capture, the U.S. Army quickly retracted the statement, claiming it was a weather balloon. This event, coupled with subsequent government explanations and retractions, fueled decades of conspiracy theories alleging a cover-up of extraterrestrial contact.

1947 Military Balloon Crash 🔗

This section details the initial event and its immediate aftermath. In 1947, rancher W.W. “Mac” Brazel discovered debris on his property near Corona, New Mexico. The debris consisted of tinfoil, rubber, tape, and wooden beams. Unaware of the ongoing “flying disc craze,” Brazel initially didn’t connect the debris to UFOs. However, after visiting Corona, his uncle suggested it could be from a “flying disk.” Brazel reported the findings to Sheriff George Wilcox, who contacted Roswell Army Air Field (RAAF).

RAAF sent Major Jesse Marcel and Captain Sheridan Cavitt to investigate. A press release issued by public information officer Walter Haut announced the military’s recovery of a “flying disc.” This announcement made international headlines but was quickly retracted. General Roger Ramey and weather officer Irving Newton identified the material as a weather balloon at a press conference.

UFO Conspiracy Theories (1947–1978) 🔗

This section explores the period between the initial incident and the rise of modern Roswell conspiracy theories. The Roswell debris retrieval faded from public attention for three decades. However, belief in government UFO cover-ups grew, fueled by hoaxes and legends of crashed spaceships and alien bodies in New Mexico. The Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax introduced the idea of recovered alien bodies, which later became associated with Roswell. The concept of “Hangar 18,” a fictional location at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, emerged as a storage site for alien craft and bodies.

Roswell Conspiracy Theories (1978–1994) 🔗

This section details the resurgence of interest in Roswell and the development of modern conspiracy theories. In 1978, ufologist Stanton Friedman interviewed Jesse Marcel, who stated that the “weather balloon” explanation was a cover story and that he believed the debris was extraterrestrial. This interview, along with subsequent media attention, reignited interest in the Roswell incident.

The 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and Bill Moore popularized Marcel’s account and added the claim of alien bodies found on the Plains of San Agustin. The book also connected Marcel’s account to Lydia Sleppy, a former teletype operator who claimed she was ordered to stop transmitting a story about crashed saucer wreckage.

The Majestic 12 hoax, involving faked government documents, emerged in the 1980s, further fueling conspiracy theories. Glenn Dennis, a former mortician, provided an account of extraterrestrial corpses, which was endorsed by prominent Roswell ufologists.

Competing accounts of the Roswell incident led to a schism among ufologists in the early 1990s. UFO Crash at Roswell by Kevin Randle and Donald Schmitt added testimony from new witnesses. Crash at Corona by Stanton Friedman and Don Berliner introduced the idea of two crashed saucers and eight aliens. The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell by Randle and Schmitt proposed a new crash site and a different group of archaeologists.

Air Force Response 🔗

This section outlines the official government response to the growing Roswell conspiracy theories. Under pressure from New Mexico congressman Steven Schiff and the General Accounting Office (GAO), the Air Force published reports in the mid-1990s. The initial 1994 report admitted that the weather balloon explanation was a cover story for Project Mogul, a military surveillance program. The 1995 report, The Roswell Report: Fact vs. Fiction in the New Mexico Desert, supported this with documentation that narrowed the cause of the debris to a specific Mogul balloon train. The 1997 report, The Roswell Report: Case Closed, detailed how eyewitness accounts of military personnel loading aliens into “body bags” matched the Air Force’s procedures for retrieving parachute test dummies.

Later Theories and Hoaxes (1994–Present) 🔗

This section covers the continued development of Roswell theories and hoaxes in recent decades. Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, a pseudo-documentary, played a major role in shaping popular opinion of Roswell. The film centered around Ray Santilli’s hoaxed footage of an alien autopsy.

In 1997, retired army intelligence officer Philip J. Corso released The Day After Roswell, alleging that he was shown a nonhuman body and helped oversee a project to reverse engineer recovered crash debris.

Other theories include Annie Jacobsen’s Area 51: An Uncensored History of America’s Top Secret Military Base, which featured a claim that Nazi doctor Josef Mengele was recruited by Soviet leader Joseph Stalin to produce “grotesque, child-size aviators.”

Explanations 🔗

This section presents the explanations for the Roswell incident, focusing on Project Mogul and anthropomorphic dummies. The Air Force reports identified Project Mogul as the source of the 1947 debris and concluded that other alien crash accounts were likely misidentified military programs or accidents. The 1997 Air Force report concluded that the alleged “bodies” reported by later eyewitnesses came from memories of accidents involving military casualties and memories of the recovery of anthropomorphic dummies.

Cultural Impact 🔗

This section explores the impact of the Roswell incident on tourism, commercialization, and popular fiction. Roswell’s tourism industry is based on ufology museums and businesses, as well as alien-themed iconography. A yearly UFO festival has been held since 1995.

The incident has been depicted in numerous films and television shows, including Hangar 18, Independence Day, The X-Files, and Roswell.

Widespread speculation of a cover-up led to United States presidents being questioned about the Roswell incident.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_UFO_incident

item.title: Calvine UFO photograph
item.description:
Calvine UFO photograph 🔗

The Calvine UFO photograph, also known as the Calvine Sighting, refers to a reported UFO sighting near Calvine, Perthshire, Scotland, in August 1990. Two men reported witnessing a diamond-shaped craft while walking on the moors. They took photographs of the object as it hovered silently before ascending vertically and disappearing. The Daily Record newspaper received the story and the original prints and negatives, which were then passed to the Ministry of Defence (MOD). The original materials disappeared, and the story was never published. Investigative journalist David Clarke has led efforts to locate the witnesses. The case gained public interest over the years, with partial documentation released by The National Archives in 2009. An original photograph was discovered by Clarke and published in the Daily Mail in 2022, leading to significant media coverage.

Historical background 🔗

This section provides context for the Calvine sighting within the broader history of UFO photography. It mentions Nick Pope, a former Ministry of Defence desk officer, who included the Calvine sighting in his 1996 book, Open Skies, Closed Minds. Pope described the sighting as intriguing and noted that the MOD’s analysis concluded the photos were likely genuine. The object was described as a solid craft, at least the size of a Harrier or Hawk fighter jet. Sean Kirkpatrick, former director of the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, has suggested the image is a reflection and may have been doctored.

Release of MOD files 🔗

This section details how the Calvine case gained more public attention after 2008 when the National Archives began releasing MOD UFO reports. David Clarke supervised the release and publication of these files. Among the released documents were materials related to the Calvine sighting, including a government briefing and handwritten summary. Two poor-quality photocopies of images were also included. These files revealed that DI55, a branch of the Directorate of Scientific and Technical Intelligence (DSTI), investigated the images along with a RAF photo analyst agency. Clarke later explored the Calvine incident in his book, The UFO Files.

2015 Channel 5 documentary 🔗

The release of information from the National Archives, along with publicity from Clarke and Pope, led to increasing public interest in the case. In 2015, the incident was featured in the Channel 5 documentary series Conspiracy. The episode, titled “Alien Cover-Up”, included interviews with Clarke and Pope and featured a reconstruction of the sighting. A graphic artist recreated the Calvine photograph for the program, which was later mistaken by some for a genuine image. Pope has speculated on potential links to the alleged Aurora project.

Discovery of the Calvine photograph 🔗

This section describes the renewed investigation led by David Clarke in 2018 to locate the missing photographs and witnesses. Clarke’s interest was sparked by a Defence Intelligence Officer’s claim that the witnesses had photographed a classified U.S. black project platform. Clarke and his team interviewed former MOD staff and conducted public searches. In 2020, Scottish UFOlogist Straiph Wilson launched a search for the hill walkers. Clarke eventually tracked down retired RAF Press Officer Craig Lindsay, who had kept the original photograph for over 32 years. Lindsay donated the print and other items to Sheffield Hallam University’s Special Collection. Andrew Robinson, a photographic specialist, produced high-resolution digital copies and conducted an in-depth analysis, concluding that the photograph is genuine.

The search for Kevin Russell 🔗

This section focuses on the search for a person named Kevin Russell, whose name was written on the back of the original Calvine photograph. The name was believed to be that of one of the witnesses. Despite contacting over 400 people with that name, Clarke’s team was unable to identify the witness. A person named Kevin Russell who worked at a hotel in Pitlochry was identified, but he denied any knowledge of the UFO. Nick Pope acknowledges being aware of the name Kevin Russell but declined to comment.

The Program documentary (2024) 🔗

This section discusses the documentary The Program by James Fox, released in December 2024, which features the Calvine UFO case. Fox interviewed David Clarke and Robinson in Sheffield and Lindsay in Scotland. The film explores the U.S. congressional effort to uncover government knowledge about UFOs and UAPs and includes an in-depth review of the Calvine case.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Calvine_UFO

item.title: Unidentified flying object
item.description:
Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) 🔗

An unidentified flying object (UFO), also known as unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP), is defined as an object or phenomenon observed in the sky that cannot be readily identified or explained. While reports of unusual aerial sightings date back centuries, the term “UFO” gained prominence after World War II, particularly during the Space Age. Investigations into UFO reports have been conducted by governments, organizations, and individuals, but no definitive confirmation of claims suggesting extraterrestrial origins or other unconventional explanations has emerged. Skeptics often attribute UFO sightings to misidentified natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, or hoaxes.

Terminology 🔗

The terms “flying saucers” or “flying discs” were initially used to describe UFOs, stemming from the Kenneth Arnold incident. Captain Edward J. Ruppelt of the USAF coined the acronym “UFO” to encompass a broader range of reported shapes and performances. “Unidentified aerial phenomena” (UAP) emerged later, gaining traction in the 21st century due to negative connotations associated with “UFO.” The term “extra-terrestrial vehicle” (ETV) is sometimes used to distinguish between extraterrestrial and earthbound explanations for UFOs.

Identification 🔗

Most UFOs, upon investigation, are identified as ordinary objects or phenomena. Common sources of UFO reports include aircraft, astronomical objects, balloons, hoaxes, light phenomena, other atmospheric objects and phenomena, and psychological effects. Studies have shown that misidentification of prosaic phenomena, often due to inexperience or misperception, is a primary factor in UFO sightings. Astronomer Andrew Fraknoi encourages critical thinking when evaluating UFO claims, suggesting that thorough investigation often reveals less mystery than initially perceived.

History 🔗

Early history before the 20th century 🔗

Throughout history, people have observed unusual sights in the sky, including comets, meteors, planets, and atmospheric optical phenomena. These events were often interpreted as supernatural portents or religious omens. While some UFO enthusiasts draw parallels between religious symbols in medieval paintings and UFO reports, art historians typically offer conventional religious interpretations.

Examples of pre-contemporary reports include:

  • Julius Obsequens’ Liber de prodigiis, which describes objects moving through the sky in ancient Rome.
  • Shen Kuo’s Dream Pool Essays, which recounts eyewitness testimony of a flying object with opening doors and blinding light in 11th-century China.
  • Woodcuts from the 16th century depicting celestial phenomena over Nuremberg and Basel, which some connect to ancient astronaut claims.
  • A report in the Denison Daily News in 1878, where a farmer described seeing a large, dark, circular object resembling a saucer.

20th century and after 🔗

During World War II, Allied and Axis pilots reported seeing round, glowing fireballs known as “foo fighters.” In 1946, the Swedish military collected over 2,000 reports of unidentified aerial objects, referred to as “ghost rockets.”

The modern UFO phenomenon gained momentum with the media frenzy surrounding Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting near Mount Rainier. Arnold described seeing “flying saucers,” sparking widespread public interest. Weeks later, the Roswell incident occurred, involving the recovery of debris from a downed observation balloon.

In the 1950s, “saucer clubs” emerged, and books like Donald Keyhoe’s The Flying Saucers Are Real popularized the extraterrestrial hypothesis. Media speculation intensified, particularly during the 1952 UFO scare in Washington, D.C.

From 1947, the U.S. Air Force investigated UFO reports through Project Sign, Project Grudge, and Project Blue Book. Project Blue Book cataloged 12,618 sightings. The Condon Report in 1968 concluded that further UFO studies were not justified.

From the 1960s to 1990s, UFOs became integrated into popular culture, with alien abduction accounts like the Barney and Betty Hill incident gaining prominence. Films like Close Encounters of the Third Kind and Alien, along with TV series like In Search of… and The X-Files, fueled public fascination.

In December 2017, media attention resurfaced with the revelation of the secret Advanced Aviation Threat Identification Program. Leaked Pentagon UFO videos led to increased mainstream interest. In July 2021, Harvard astronomer Avi Loeb announced the Galileo Project, aiming to seek evidence of extraterrestrial artifacts. Government programs like NASA’s UAP independent study team and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office were established to investigate UFO claims. Congressional hearings were held in 2022 and 2023, featuring whistleblower claims from former U.S. Air Force officer David Grusch.

Public belief in UFOs varies, with polls indicating that a significant percentage of Americans believe UFOs are evidence of alien life.

Notable cases and incidents 🔗

Notable cases and incidents include:

  • Britain: The Rendlesham Forest incident (1980).
  • France: The Valensole UFO incident (1965) and the Trans-en-Provence Case (1981).
  • United States: The Kecksburg UFO incident (1965), the Travis Walton abduction claim (1975), and the Phoenix Lights (1997).

Famous hoaxes include the Maury Island incident and the Gulf Breeze UFO incident.

Investigations of reports 🔗

UFO reports have been investigated by governments and academics in various countries. No official government investigation has definitively confirmed that UFOs are real, physical objects of extraterrestrial origin.

Well-known government studies include:

  • The ghost rockets investigation by the Swedish military (1946–1947).
  • Project Blue Book, Project Sign, and Project Grudge by the USAF (1947–1969).
  • Project Twinkle investigation into green fireballs (1948–1951).
  • Project Blue Book Special Report No. 14 by the Battelle Memorial Institute.
  • Brazilian Air Force’s Operação Prato (1977).
  • France’s GEPAN/SEPRA/GEIPAN (1977–present).
  • Uruguay’s government investigation (1989–present).

Americas 🔗

  • Brazil (1952–2016): The National Archives of Brazil has been receiving documentation from the Brazilian Air Force regarding UFO investigations.
  • Chile (c. 1968): The SEFAA (previously CEFAA) receives case reports from the public, civil aviators, and the Chilean Air Force.
  • Canada (c. 1950): The Department of National Defence has investigated UFO reports, including the Falcon Lake incident and the Shag Harbour UFO incident. Early studies included Project Magnet and Project Second Storey.
  • United States: U.S. investigations include Project Sign, Project Grudge, Project Blue Book, Project Twinkle, the CIA’s Directorate of Science & Technology study, the Robertson Panel, the Brookings Report, the Condon Committee, the RAND Corporation study, the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON), the National Investigations Committee On Aerial Phenomena (NICAP), the Center for UFO Studies (CUFOS), the Sturrock panel, the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office.

USAAF and FBI response to the 1947 sightings 🔗

Following a surge in sightings in 1947, the USAAF and FBI began a formal investigation. A preliminary defense estimate concluded that “something is really flying around.”

USAF 🔗

Projects Sign (1947–1949), Grudge (1948–1951), and Blue Book (1951–1970) 🔗

Project Sign’s final report stated that there was not enough data to determine the origin of some UFOs. In August 1948, Sign investigators wrote a top-secret intelligence estimate concluding an extraterrestrial origin, but the Air Force Chief of Staff ordered it destroyed.

Another classified U.S. study by the CIA in 1952 concluded that UFOs were real physical objects of potential threat to national security.

Project Sign was dismantled and became Project Grudge, which was later reorganized as Project Blue Book. J. Allen Hynek, a scientific advisor for Project Blue Book, became critical of the program’s scientific rigor.

USAF Regulation 200-2 (1953–1954) 🔗

Air Force Regulation 200-2 defined an Unidentified Flying Object (“UFOB”) and outlined procedures for investigation and reporting.

Blue Book and the Condon Committee (1968–1970) 🔗

The Condon Report in 1968 arrived at a negative conclusion regarding UFOs. Project Blue Book closed down in 1970. However, a 1969 USAF document, known as the Bolender memo, revealed that non-public U.S. government UFO investigations continued after 1970.

FOIA release of documents in 1978 🔗

Documents released under the Freedom of Information Act in 1978 indicated serious behind-the-scenes

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO

item.title: Black triangle (UFO)
item.description:
Black Triangles 🔗

Black triangles are a type of unidentified flying object (UFO) characterized by their triangular shape and dark color. These objects are typically observed at night and are often described as large, silent, hovering, moving slowly, and displaying pulsating, colored lights that can be turned off.

British Sightings and UK Ministry of Defence Report 🔗

This section discusses the analysis of black triangle sightings by the UK Ministry of Defence in a declassified report called Project Condign. The report suggests that many unexplained UAP reports could be attributed to atmospheric gaseous electrically charged buoyant plasmas. It also mentions that some observations might be due to meteor entry into the atmosphere. The report proposes that a field with undetermined characteristics can exist between charged buoyant objects in loose formation, creating a triangular shape where light reflection doesn’t occur. A recommendation from the report advises aircraft to avoid intercepting these objects and instead position them astern to reduce collision risks. The report also speculates that plasma formations could induce vivid but incorrect perceptions in observers. Mark Stenhoff and Adrian James are mentioned as authors who doubt the scientific veracity of the Project Condign report.

Other Sightings 🔗

This section details various black triangle UFO sightings reported across different locations and time periods.

1980s Hudson Valley Sightings 🔗

During the early 1980s, hundreds of people reported seeing UFOs over or near the Hudson River in New York state. These objects were described as hovering or slowly flying V-shaped objects with colorful lights. Some pilots claimed responsibility for these sightings, stating that the objects were ultralight aircraft flown in formation.

1989–1992 Belgian Wave 🔗

The Belgian UFO wave began in November 1989. On November 29, over thirty groups of witnesses and three police groups documented a large, flat, triangular object with lights underneath flying at low altitude without making any sound. A report titled The Belgian UFO Wave of 1989–1992 – A Neglected Hypothesis suggests that some sightings could be explained by helicopters, with the lack of noise attributed to engine noise in witnesses’ automobiles or strong winds. The Belgian Air Force attempted to intercept an object detected by radar during this wave, but the pilots did not visually confirm the object. Brian Dunning is mentioned as a skeptic who disputes the entire Belgian UFO wave.

1997 Phoenix Lights Incident 🔗

This section focuses on the widely reported “Phoenix Lights” events, where multiple unidentified objects were observed near Phoenix, Arizona, beginning on March 13, 1997. Some objects appeared in a large “V” formation and lingered for several minutes. Residents reported that one of the black triangles was over a mile wide and drifted slowly over their houses. The US Air Force concluded that the military had been testing aircraft-launched flares during that period.

2000 Southern Illinois Incident 🔗

The “St. Clair Triangle” sighting occurred on January 5, 2000, over several towns in Southern Illinois. The incident was featured in television shows, and Sufjan Stevens included it in his song “Concerning the UFO Sighting Near Highland, Illinois.” The FAA suggested that the sightings might have been due to an advertising blimp operated by the American Blimp Company. William Stage is mentioned as a source, and Eric Mack is cited for debunking his own UFO sighting.

2004–2006 Tinley Park Lights 🔗

Multiple witnesses in Tinley Park and Oak Forest, Illinois, reported seeing three red lights hovering in a triangular formation on several occasions between 2004 and 2006. Some witnesses captured the lights in photographs and videos. The incident was examined in a Dateline NBC episode and in an episode of the television series UFO Hunters. Julie Dekker is mentioned in connection with remembering the “Tinley Park lights.”

2008 Stephenville, Texas 🔗

A mass sighting occurred in Stephenville, Texas, around January 8, 2008. The Netflix documentary series Encounters claims that the black triangles seen had what looked like insects or a praying mantis inside. Angelia Joiner is mentioned as reporting on the possible UFO sighting in the Stephenville Empire-Tribune.

Military Aircraft 🔗

This section explores the possibility that classified military aircraft could be responsible for many black triangle UFO reports. Sightings have been reported over Antelope Valley in southern California, near military research and testing areas like Edwards Air Force Base and United States Air Force Plant 42. The National Institute for Discovery Science suggested that black triangles might be U.S. Air Force craft. The Northrop TR-3A Black Manta, a speculative surveillance aircraft, is mentioned, but its existence is not confirmed. Gregory T. Pope is cited regarding America’s new secret aircraft, and Global Security is referenced for information on the TR-3A. Geoscientist Ben McGee is identified as suggesting that border patrol drones with infrared lights could explain some black triangles. Natalie Wolchover is cited in relation to McGee’s explanation.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_triangle_(UFO)

item.title: UFO (disambiguation)
item.description:
UFO (disambiguation) 🔗

This page serves as a disambiguation for the term “UFO,” which primarily refers to an unidentified flying object, an aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified or explained. However, “UFO” is also used in various other contexts.

Computer Technology 🔗

This section lists various uses of “UFO” in the realm of computer technology. It includes:

  • .ufo: The file extension for Ulead PhotoImpact documents.
  • Unified File and Object (UFO): An object storage architecture.
  • UHF Follow-On satellite: A series of US military communications satellites.
  • Unified Font Object: An XML-based open format for digital fonts.
  • Unified Foundational Ontology: An upper ontology for conceptual modeling.

Art, Entertainment and Media 🔗

This section covers the diverse applications of “UFO” in art, entertainment, and media, broken down into film and television, music, and video games.

Film and Television 🔗

This subsection lists several films and television series with “UFO” in their titles:

  • UFO (1956 film): Directed by Winston Jones.
  • U.F.O. (1993 film): Starring Roy “Chubby” Brown.
  • U.F.O. (2012 film): Featuring Jean-Claude Van Damme.
  • UFO (2018 film): Directed by Ryan Eslinger, starring Alex Sharp and Gillian Anderson, focusing on an airport sighting.
  • UFO (2022 film): A Turkish Netflix film.
  • UFO (American TV series): A 2021 television documentary by J.J. Abrams.
  • UFO (British TV series): A 1970s TV series by Gerry Anderson.
  • UFOs (TV series): A 2021 French TV series.
  • UFO Ultramaiden Valkyrie: A 2000s manga and anime television series.

Music 🔗

This subsection is further divided into bands and performers, albums, and songs.

Bands and Performers 🔗

This section lists musical artists and groups using “UFO” in their names:

  • UFO (musician): A Danish hip hop artist, rapper, and singer (born 1981).
  • Ufo361: A German rapper (born 1988).
  • UFO (band): An English hard rock band.
  • UFO: The original name of the English R&B group better known as JLS.
  • UFO Yepha: A Danish hip hop duo.
  • The Unidentified Flying Objects: An American rock band.
  • United Future Organization: A Japanese jazz duo.

Albums 🔗

This section lists albums titled “UFO”:

  • U.F.O. (album): A 1969 album by Jim Sullivan.
  • UFO EP: By Torch.
  • UFO (Newton Faulkner EP): By Newton Faulkner.

Songs 🔗

This section lists songs titled “UFO”:

  • “UFO” (Mallrat song featuring Allday): (2018)
  • “UFO” (Pink Lady song): (1977)
  • “UFO”: A song by ESG on their EP ESG (1981).
  • “UFO” (Sneaky Sound System song): (2007)
  • “U.F.O.” (Coldplay song): (2011)
  • “UFO” (Vigiland song): (2014)
  • “U.F.O.”: A song by Blonde Redhead on their album La Mia Vita Violenta (1995).
  • “UFO”: A song by D-Block Europe and Aitch from the album The Blue Print: Us vs. Them (2020).

Other Musical Works 🔗

  • UFO (Michael Daugherty composition): A musical composition.
  • UFOetry: A multimedia UFO rock opera.

Video Games 🔗

This section lists video games with “UFO” in their titles, including the UFO Defense family of games and other unrelated titles.

UFO Defense Family 🔗

  • UFO: Enemy Unknown (1994): Also known as X-COM: UFO Defense.
  • UFO: Aftermath (2003)
  • UFO: Aftershock (2005)
  • UFO: Afterlight (2007)
  • UFO: Alien Invasion (2003)

Other Video Games 🔗

  • UFO (1989): By Sublogic.
  • UFO Kamen Yakisoban (1994): For Super Famicom.
  • U.F.O.s (1997): An adventure game by Artech.
  • UFO: A Day in the Life (1999): By Love-de-Lic.
  • UFO: Extraterrestrials (2007): By Chaos Concept.
  • Undefined Fantastic Object (2009): The twelfth entry in the Touhou Project series by ZUN.

Other Works 🔗

  • UFOs: The Greatest Stories: A 1996 short-story anthology by Martin H. Greenberg.

Games and Sports 🔗

  • Claw vending machine: Also known as UFO.
  • UFO: A style of delivery in Ten-pin bowling.

Clubs 🔗

This section lists clubs with “UFO” in their names:

  • Ufo (Club, Berlin): An Acid House club.
  • UFO Club: A London underground club.

Products and Services 🔗

This section lists products and services branded with “UFO”:

  • UFO: A brand of instant yakisoba.
  • UFO (restaurant): A restaurant in Slovakia.
  • UFO (ride): An amusement park ride.

Other Uses 🔗

This section lists other miscellaneous uses of the acronym “UFO”:

  • United Farmers of Ontario: A Canadian political party c. 1920s.
  • UFO: A variant of float b-boy move.
  • Ufo (wasp): A genus of wasps.
  • UFO 34 (yacht): A sailboat.
  • UFO Radio: A radio station in Taiwan.
  • Uranium Fluorine Oxygen: Representing the chemical elements.
  • Ultra Fast Outflows: Winds that come from supermassive black holes.
  • University of French Ontario: Referring to the Université de l’Ontario français.

See Also 🔗

This section provides links to related disambiguation pages and topics:

  • U-Foes: A Marvel Comics supervillain team.
  • Unidentified flying object (disambiguation)
  • Flying saucer (disambiguation)
  • Alien (disambiguation)

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_(disambiguation)

item.title: My Guardian Alien
item.description:
My Guardian Alien 🔗

A 2024 Philippine television drama series broadcast by GMA Network. It is a science fiction drama directed by Zig Madamba Dulay, starring Marian Rivera. The series premiered on April 1, 2024, and concluded on June 28, 2024, with 65 episodes. Originally titled Against All Odds, it was later renamed. The series is also available for streaming on YouTube.

Premise 🔗

The plot centers around Katherine, who dies in a shooting accident. During her funeral, an alien “pod” lands on Earth, and the alien takes Katherine’s form.
