item.title: Alien Nation
item.description:
Alien Nation 🔗

A science fiction police procedural television series that aired on Fox from 1989 to 1990. It’s based on the 1988 film Alien Nation.

Plot 🔗

The series is set in the near future, beginning in 1990, after a flying saucer crashes in the Mojave Desert. The ship contains the Tenctonese, a race of extraterrestrials escaping slavery. They are accepted as immigrants to the US, and the series explores their integration into American society. Storylines often address themes of racism and bigotry, using the Newcomers as a stand-in for discriminated minorities. The series uses social commentary to illustrate what it means to be human and the often bizarre rituals we observe.

Cast 🔗

  • Detective Matthew “Matt” Sikes: Played by Gary Graham, a human detective partnered with George Francisco.
  • Detective George Francisco: Played by Eric Pierpoint, a Newcomer detective partnered with Matthew Sikes.
  • Susan Francisco: Played by Michele Scarabelli, George’s wife, a Newcomer advertising businesswoman.
  • Emily Francisco: Played by Lauren Woodland, George and Susan’s young daughter.
  • Buck Francisco: Played by Sean Six, George and Susan’s initially delinquent teenage son.
  • Cathy Frankel: Played by Terri Treas, Matt’s Newcomer neighbor and on-off girlfriend, a bio-chemist.
  • Albert Einstein: Played by Jeff Marcus, a timid Newcomer janitor working at the police department.
  • Cpt. Bryon Grazer: Played by Ron Fassler, Matt and George’s human superior officer.
  • Beatrice Zepeda: Played by Jenny Gago, a human detective in Matt and George’s squad.
  • Burns: Played by Jeff Doucette, a human photographer.
  • Sergeant Dobbs: Played by Lawrence Hilton-Jacobs, a human police officer.
  • Jill: Played by Molly Morgan, a human girl and Emily’s friend.
  • Uncle Moodri: Played by James Greene, an eccentric but wise Newcomer and member of the Francisco family.

Production 🔗

Kenneth Johnson, responsible for other science-fiction television series, was approached for the television adaptation of the 1988 film Alien Nation. He initially had no interest in the project but was later inspired to create a series focusing on social commentary about the integration of a new minority group.

Changes from the film 🔗

Several changes were made from the original film. The human detective Matthew Sykes was played by James Caan in the film, but Gary Graham in the TV series. Detective George Francisco was played by Mandy Patinkin in the film, but Eric Pierpoint in the TV series. The TV series explores Newcomer culture more deeply than the film. Francisco’s family also differs, with a daughter, Emily, added to the TV series.

Cancellation 🔗

The series ran for one season on Fox. Despite building a strong fan base, the show was cancelled due to the network’s financial difficulties. The season ended on a cliffhanger, and popular demand led to the unproduced second season premiere being adapted as a novel and comic book. Years later, Fox produced five television films to continue the story.

Episodes 🔗

The series consists of 22 episodes, each dealing with the integration of the Newcomers into human society and the challenges they face. The episodes often involve police procedural elements, with Sikes and Francisco investigating crimes involving both humans and Newcomers.

Television films 🔗

Five television films continued the story after the series’ cancellation:

  • Alien Nation: Dark Horizon (1994)
  • Alien Nation: Body and Soul (1995)
  • Alien Nation: Millennium (1996)
  • Alien Nation: The Enemy Within (1996)
  • Alien Nation: The Udara Legacy (1997)

Home media 🔗

The complete series was released on DVD by 20th Century Fox in 2006. The five television films were later released as a collection.

Revival 🔗

In 2009, Syfy announced a new take on the series with Tim Minear writing. However, the series was later cancelled. In 2015, a remake was reported to be in the works with Art Marcum and Matt Holloway writing the script.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Nation_(TV_series)

item.title: Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family
item.description:
Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family 🔗

Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family is an Indian animated science fiction comedy series that premiered on Nickelodeon India on April 24, 2023. The show is directed by Abhijit Daripkar and Santosh Pednekar and produced by Hi-Tech Animation. The title track’s lyrics are by Gulzar, with music by Simaab Sen. The series revolves around a 12-year-old boy named Abhimanyu who can transform into an alien, focusing on his efforts to fit into human society, make friends, hide his identity, and overcome challenges.

Synopsis 🔗

The series tells the story of Abhimanyu, a 12-year-old who can transform into an alien. The narrative focuses on his journey to integrate with humans, form friendships, conceal his true identity, and tackle various challenges. It also highlights his family’s adaptation struggles. Characters are shown in both human and alien forms.

Cast 🔗

The voice cast includes:

  • Jasleen Singh as Abhimanyu
  • Merlin James as Arya
  • Mohit Sinha as Naveen
  • Roop Thakkar as Kookie
  • Sanchit Wartak as Supremo of Planet Zonga and Mr. Ghotala
  • Asavari Ajinkya as Mrs. Ghotala
  • Pratik Verma as Ronnie

Characters 🔗

  • Abhimanyu: The protagonist, a smart and strong alien who can assimilate powers from objects. He must conceal his abilities to maintain his human disguise.
  • Arya: Abhimanyu’s sister and the first-in-command on the Earth mission, serving as Supremo’s eyes and ears. Her elastic tongue helps her solve problems.
  • Naveen: Abhimanyu’s father, who can turn people into statues with a touch. He is timid and clumsy, struggling with physical contact.
  • Kookie: Abhimanyu’s mother, who can move massive objects and manipulate wind. She is fascinated by Earth fashion and enjoys shopping.
  • Supremo of Planet Zonga: The commander of the aliens’ Earth mission, instructing them to maintain human forms.
  • Mr. Ghotala: The Kumar family’s neighbor, an alien research scientist who suspects aliens are nearby. His catchphrase is “Aiga!”.
  • Mrs. Ghotala: The neighbor and friend of the Kumar family. Her catchphrase is “Sahi samay par sahi jagah tapakne ki toh meri aadat hai!”.
  • Ronnie: The Ghotalas’ son, a bully who uses his height and fashion sense to cause trouble. He is Abhimanyu’s enemy.

Production 🔗

Viacom18’s Kids TV Network produces the series, and Nickelodeon distributes it. Hi-Tech Animation conceptualized and produced the show using 3D animation techniques with 2D rendering.

Episodes 🔗

Season 1 🔗

Season 1 consists of 70 episodes, with titles including “Being Human,” “Ghotala Dinner,” “Alien Sunglasses,” “Beware Of Dog,” “Charge Ho Jao,” and many others.

Reception 🔗

Garima Das of Outlook India included Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family in a list of sci-fi shows to watch, highlighting the show’s premise and the challenges faced by the alien characters as they navigate human life.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abhimanyu_Ki_Alien_Family

item.title: Alien TV (2019 TV series)
item.description:
Alien TV (2019 TV series) 🔗

Alien TV is a live-action/CG animation television series that premiered on 9Go! in Australia on November 23, 2019, and on Netflix. The show was created by Ian Brown and developed by Doug Hadders and Adam Rotstein. The series follows a television news crew of extraterrestrials named Ixbee, Pixbee, and Squee, who are sent to Earth to learn about the planet.

Cast 🔗

The main voice cast includes Rob Tinkler as Ixbee, Julie Lemieux as Pixbee, John Cleland as Squee, Kyle Dooley as Squood, and Rupert Degas as the Translator.

Episodes 🔗

The series consists of two seasons. Season 1 was released on August 21, 2020, and Season 2 was released on March 19, 2021. There are no plans for a season 3.

Series Overview 🔗

The series is divided into two seasons, with 13 episodes each. Season 1 was released in 2020, and Season 2 in 2021. Each episode contains three segments.

Season 1 (2020) 🔗

Season 1 consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. Each segment focuses on the aliens’ experiences with different aspects of Earth culture and activities, such as bicycles, gymnastics, camping, playgrounds, art, gum, gyms, birthdays, restaurants, BBQs, offices, Halloween, pizza, magic, cleaning, arcades, dumplings, presents, junkyards, spas, love, movies, kindergarten, sickness, babies, supermarkets, tea, weddings, Loch Ness, soccer, skateboards, mannequins, survival, toyshops, laundromats, yoga, Santa, trophies, and makeup. Each segment is directed by Ian Brown and written by various writers, including Doug Hadders, Adam Rotstein, Jeff Sager, Brian Hartigan, Shawn Kalb, Cleon Prineas, Laurie Elliott, Bruce Griffiths, Simon Dodd, Jennifer Daley, Thomas Duncan-Watt and Naomi Jardine.

Season 2 (2021) 🔗

Season 2 also consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. The segments continue to explore the aliens’ interactions with Earth, featuring topics such as trains, barbershops, gnomes, florists, fashion, teeth, pools, dinner parties, skiing, joke shops, the Outback, fire halls, baby showers, yard sales, aquariums, dance, international games, shopping, school, holidays, lucha libre, cars, sleep, golf, airplanes, water parks, mail, music, bowling, gardening, museums, Bollywood, castles, ballet, energy, leprechauns, glasses, trials, and scary things. Ian Brown directs all segments, and the writing credits include Naomi Jardine, Jerome Simpson, Bruce Griffiths, Jennifer Daley, Jeff Sager, Kyle Dooley, Simon Dodd, Cleon Prineas, Brian Hartigan, and Gina Roncoli Bruce Griffiths.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_TV

item.title: In Search of Aliens
item.description:
In Search of Aliens 🔗

In Search of Aliens is a 2014 American television series that aired on the H2 channel. The show is presented by Giorgio A. Tsoukalos, a prominent figure from Ancient Aliens, and explores topics related to pseudoscience, ufology, and conspiracy theories, particularly the ancient astronaut theory.

Episodes 🔗

This section lists the titles of all ten episodes of the single season of In Search of Aliens. The episodes cover a range of topics, including:

  • The Hunt for Atlantis
  • Nazi Time Travelers
  • The Mystery of Loch Ness
  • The Roswell Rock
  • Searching for Bigfoot
  • The Mystery of the Cyclops
  • The Mystery of Puma Punku
  • The Founding of America
  • The Mystery of Nazca
  • The Alien Code

Criticism 🔗

The show has faced criticism from reviewers and organizations. Jason Colavito criticized the show for lacking a clear thesis and for Tsoukalos’ apparent skepticism towards his interviewees’ claims. The Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC), through Alexander Zaitchik’s Hatewatch blog, has criticized shows like In Search of Aliens for promoting “racist pseudo-scholarship” and raising the profile of figures like Jan Udo Holey, whose antisemitic works have been banned in Europe.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics and television programs, including:

  • List of topics characterized as pseudoscience
  • Pseudoarchaeology
  • Ancient Aliens
  • Unsealed Alien Files
  • In Search of… (TV series)

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including links to History.com, Jason Colavito’s website, and the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Hatewatch blog.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to the show’s page on IMDb.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_Search_of_Aliens

item.title: Michigan "swamp gas" UFO reports
item.description:
1966 US UFO Sightings: Michigan “Swamp Gas” UFO Reports 🔗

This article details the mass sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) that occurred in Michigan during March 1966, specifically on March 20 and 21. These events became known as the “Michigan ‘swamp gas’ UFO reports” due to the Air Force’s controversial explanation for the sightings.

March 1966 UFO Flap 🔗

This section provides an overview of the broader context of the Michigan UFO sightings, noting that the Dexter and Hillsdale mass sightings occurred amidst a wave of UFO reports throughout southern Michigan. A map illustrates the locations of reported sightings, including Lima, Milan, Dexter, Hillsdale, and Holland.

Initial Reports 🔗

This section details the initial UFO sightings that preceded the Dexter and Hillsdale incidents. It mentions reports from Washtenaw County residents, sheriffs, and police beginning around 3:50 a.m. on March 14, describing lights moving at high speeds over Lima Township. Sightings were also reported from Monroe, Livingston, Ypsilanti, Dexter, and Sylvania. Sheriff Deputies Buford Bushroe and John Foster, along with personnel at Selfridge Air Force Base, confirmed the sightings. Deputy David Fitzpatrick captured photographs of lights over Milan on March 16.

Dexter Mass Sighting 🔗

This section focuses on the events of March 20, 1966, when Frank Mannor, his wife, and son Ronald reported seeing a red “falling star” that hovered over a marshy area near their farmhouse northwest of Dexter. Mannor contacted law enforcement, and Deputy Sheriff Stanley McFadden and his partner David Fitzpatrick investigated. The Mannors described the object as football-shaped with a ‘waffled’ texture, blinking lights, and antennae. Dexter patrolman Robert Hunawil and Dexter Chief of Police Robert Taylor were also witnesses. Approximately 60 people, including law enforcement, neighbors, and the Mannor family, reportedly witnessed the UFO.

Hillsdale Mass Sighting 🔗

This section describes the mass sighting that occurred around 9 p.m. on March 21 at Hillsdale College. Approximately 87 residents of the MacIntyre Residence Hall observed flashing lights hovering over the Arboretum. William Van Horn, Hillsdale County civil defense director, investigated and observed the lights through binoculars. Hillsdale police officers Harold Hess and Jerry Wise also witnessed the object and reported radio damage after the event.

Continued Reports 🔗

This section notes that reports of flying objects, strange sounds, and unexplained lights continued in Dexter and Hillsdale on March 22. On March 23, a teen from Monroe claimed to have taken photos of a UFO. Robert Nichols and his wife reported an object flying across a highway near Holland on March 24. Sightings were also reported over Macomb and Oakland counties, as well as Bad Axe, Flint, and Ann Arbor, on March 29.

National Attention 🔗

This section discusses the national media coverage of the Dexter sightings, noting that papers nationwide reported on the events on March 21. Wire services distributed a drawing of the reported object by a police officer. Various speculations were covered, including a theory that the UFO was filling up on swamp water to recharge its batteries.

Hynek Press Conference 🔗

This section details the involvement of J. Allen Hynek, an Air Force UFO expert, who was dispatched to investigate the Dexter and Hillsdale sightings. On March 25, Hynek held a press conference where he attributed the sightings to “marsh gas,” an explanation that was met with skepticism and derision. He dismissed the Fitzpatrick photograph as being of the moon and Venus.

Reactions 🔗

This section describes the reactions to Hynek’s “swamp gas” explanation. Congressman Gerald R. Ford called for a Congressional investigation into the sightings. Life Magazine and CBS Reports covered the case.

Congressional Hearing 🔗

This section discusses Hynek’s testimony before the House Armed Services Committee on April 6, alongside Air Force Secretary Harold Brown and Bluebook chief Major Hector Quintanilla. Hynek broke with the Air Force’s stance and suggested that some aspects of UFOs merited serious study.

Aftermath and Legacy 🔗

This section examines the long-term impact of the Michigan UFO sightings. The sightings were listed as a top-ten story for 1966 in Michigan. Alan Hynek, who popularized the swamp gas hypothesis, later argued that the topic merited serious study. The phrase “swamp gas” became associated with skepticism of government conclusions. The incident has been referenced in popular culture, including The X-Files and Men in Black.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan_%22swamp_gas%22_UFO_reports

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Flying Saucer 🔗

A flying saucer, or flying disc, is a purported type of disc-shaped unidentified flying object (UFO). The term originated in 1947 when US news media reported pilot Kenneth Arnold’s claim of seeing objects flying near his airplane over Washington State. The news reports included implausible speed estimates and preceded a wave of sightings across the US, including the Roswell incident and the Flight 105 UFO sighting. A National Guard pilot died in 1948 while pursuing a flying saucer. Civilian research groups and conspiracy theories developed around the topic, and the concept spread to other countries. Early reports speculated about secret military technology, but flying saucers became associated with aliens by 1950. The terms unidentified flying object (UFO) and unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) have gradually replaced the term over time.

An aerial photo taken over Lake Cote, Costa Rica, by Sergio Loaiza in 1971 is included.

In science fiction, UFO sightings, UFO conspiracy theories, and popular culture, saucers are typically piloted by nonhuman beings. Most reported sightings describe saucers in the distance and do not mention a crew. Descriptions of the craft vary considerably. Early reports emphasized speed, but the descriptions shifted over the decades to the objects mostly hovering. They are generally said to be round, sometimes with a protrusion on top, but details of the shape vary between reports. Witnesses describe flying saucers as silent or deafening, with lights of every color, and flying alone or in formation. Size estimates range from small enough to fit in a living room to over 2,000 feet (610 m) in diameter. Sightings are most frequent at night. Astronomer Donald Howard Menzel concluded that the reports were too varied to all be describing the same type of objects. Experts have identified most reported saucers as known phenomena, including astronomical objects such as Venus, airborne objects such as balloons, and optical phenomena such as sun dogs.

1950s pop culture embraced flying saucers. The discs appeared in film, television, literature, music, toys, and advertising. Their reports influenced religious movements and were the subject of military investigations. The shape became visual shorthand for alien invaders. During the 1960s, saucers waned in popularity as UFOs were reported and depicted in other shapes. Discs ceased to be viewed as the standard shape for alien spacecraft but are still often depicted, sometimes for their retro value to evoke the early Cold War era.

History 🔗

Reports of fantastical aircraft predate the first flying saucers. In antiquity, mysterious lights in the sky were interpreted as spiritual phenomena. In the 1800s, many newspapers reported massive airships with glowing lights and humming engines. These are often seen as precursors to flying saucer and UFO sightings. On January 25, 1878, the Denison Daily News printed an article in which John Martin, a local farmer, reported an object resembling a balloon flying “at wonderful speed”. The newspaper said it appeared to be about the size of a saucer from his perspective, one of the first uses of the word “saucer” in association with a UFO. An outbreak of a number of sightings of mystery airships occurred in America in 1896 and 1897. During World War II, Allied pilots reported balls of light following their planes. They named the lights foo fighters and believed they were advanced Axis aircraft.

Many aspects of the typical flying saucer first appeared in science fiction. French sociologist Bertrand Méheust noted Jean de La Hire’s 1908 novel La Roue fulgurante (The Lightning Wheel). In the novel, a flying disc-shaped machine abducts the protagonists via a beam of light. Science fiction magazine Amazing Stories began publishing “The Shaver Mystery” in 1945. Written by Richard Sharpe Shaver and edited by Raymond A. Palmer, they were science fiction tales about technologically advanced “detrimental robots” that abducted humans, but the stories were presented as a true account of Shaver’s life. Until the magazine ceased printing The Shaver Mystery, Amazing Stories’ letter column was regularly full of readers sharing their own purportedly true sightings of the robots.

Before the flying saucer was coined as a term, fantasy artwork in pulp magazines depicted flying discs. Skeptical physicist Milton Rothman noted the appearance of so-called flying saucers in the fantasy artwork of 1930s pulp science fiction magazines, by artists such as Frank R. Paul. One of Paul’s earliest depictions of a flying saucer appeared on the cover of the November 1929 issue of Hugo Gernsback’s pulp science fiction magazine Science Wonder Stories. Science fiction illustrator Frank Wu wrote that the idea of space vehicles shaped like flying saucers was imprinted in the national psyche for many years prior to 1947, when the Roswell incident took place.

Origins 🔗

The modern flying saucer concept, including the association with aliens, can be traced to the 1947 Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting. On June 24, 1947, businessman and amateur pilot Kenneth Arnold landed at the Yakima, Washington airstrip. He told staff and friends that he’d seen nine unusual airborne objects. Arnold estimated their speed at 1,700 miles per hour, beyond the capabilities of known aircraft. Newspapers soon contacted Arnold for interviews. The East Oregonian reported his supposed aircraft as “saucer-like”. In a June 26 radio interview, Arnold described them as “something like a pie plate that was cut in half with a sort of a convex triangle in the rear”. Headline writers coined the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disk” (or “disc”) for the story. Arnold later told CBS News that the early coverage “did not quote me properly […] when I described how they flew, I said that they flew like they take a saucer and throw it across the water. Most of the newspapers misunderstood and misquoted that, too. They said that I said that they were saucer-like; I said that they flew in a saucer-like fashion.” The circular shape of typical flying saucers may be due to reporters mistaking Arnold’s “saucer-like” description of motion.

Arnold’s story preceded a wave of hundreds of flying saucer reports. Lieutenant Governor of Idaho Donald S. Whitehead claimed he saw a fast-moving object resembling a meteor around the time of Arnold’s sighting. In early July, head of Air Materiel Command Nathan F. Twining told reporters that “anyone seeing the objects” should contact Wright Field. The next widely publicized report was the sighting by a United Airlines crew on July 4 of nine more disc-like objects pacing their plane over Idaho.

The public was divided on the potential origin of the saucers. Arnold told military intelligence officers he suspected the discs were experimental aircraft, and early newspapers reported Arnold saying, “I don’t know what they were—unless they were guided missiles.” News media speculated on a Soviet origin, and many war veterans connected them to the foo fighters seen during World War II. A Gallup Poll found that 90% of Americans were aware of the saucer stories, and 16 percent believed they were secret military weapons, most likely American. The most common explanation given was some type of illusion or mirage. Less than one percent believed they were alien craft. One report from Seattle, Washington, described a hammer and sickle painted onto a flying disc. The stories spread to other countries, where they were influenced by local political and social concerns. In Europe, which was still recovering from the Second World War, saucers were often reported with rocket-like features. German newspapers reported flying saucers that exploded or had tails of fire. The names for the discs were largely derived from the English “flying saucer” including the French soucoupe volante, Spanish platillo volante, Portuguese disco voador, Swedish flygande tefat, German fliegende Untertasse, and Italian disco volante.

The 1947 sightings peaked in the days after the Fourth of July and declined rapidly through mid-July. Multiple organizations offered $1,000 rewards for hard proof. In the widely reported July 7, 1947, Twin Falls saucer hoax, four teenagers in Idaho fabricated a crashed disc from jukebox parts. On July 8, the Army Air Force base at Roswell, New Mexico, issued a press release saying that they had recovered a “flying disc” from a nearby ranch; the so-called Roswell UFO incident made front-page news. International media covered the military’s announcement of a crashed disc, but within 24 hours were reporting the military’s retraction and explanation that the material was balloon debris. By July 11, the most widely reported story was a North Hollywood resident’s claim that a 30-inch galvanized iron disc containing glass radio tubes had crashed in his garden. Newspapers quoted Fire Battalion Chief Wallace Newcombe’s assessment, “It doesn’t look to me like it could fly.”

The Air Force collected over a hundred reports at Wright Field, now Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio. Air Force General Nathan Twining established Project SAUCER, later renamed Project Sign, the first in a series of UFO investigations by the US Government. Other national governments followed suit. Canada began Project Magnet and the United Kingdom launched the Flying Saucer Working Party in 1950, which attributed saucer reports to meteorological phenomena, astronomical phenomena, misidentification, optical illusions, misconceptions, or hoaxes

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_Saucers

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Purported disk-shaped aircraft 🔗

This article discusses the history, description, and cultural impact of “flying saucers,” a term popularized in the late 1940s to describe disc-shaped unidentified flying objects (UFOs). It distinguishes flying saucers from the broader category of UFOs/UAPs and explores their evolution in popular culture.

History 🔗

This section traces the origins and development of the flying saucer phenomenon.

Precursors 🔗

This subsection explores earlier reports of unusual aerial phenomena that predate the term “flying saucer.” These include:

  • Mysterious lights in the sky interpreted as spiritual phenomena in antiquity.
  • 19th-century newspaper reports of massive airships.
  • The 1878 Denison Daily News article describing an object resembling a saucer.
  • “Foo fighters” reported by Allied pilots during World War II.
  • Science fiction stories featuring disc-shaped aircraft, such as Jean de La Hire’s 1908 novel La Roue fulgurante and “The Shaver Mystery” stories in Amazing Stories magazine.
  • Fantasy artwork in pulp magazines depicting flying discs.

Origins 🔗

This subsection details the event that is credited with popularizing the term “flying saucer”:

  • The Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting on June 24, 1947, in Washington State.
  • Arnold’s description of the objects’ motion as “like a saucer skipping across the water.”
  • The media’s coining of the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disc.”
  • The subsequent wave of reported sightings across the United States, including the Flight 105 UFO sighting and the Roswell incident.
  • Early speculation about the objects’ origins, including secret military technology and Soviet aircraft.

Development 🔗

This subsection covers the evolution of the flying saucer concept and its association with extraterrestrial life:

  • The increasing association of flying saucers with extraterrestrial life in the 1950s.
  • Kenneth Arnold’s speculation about an extraterrestrial origin for the objects.
  • The emergence of unusual theories, such as Meade Layne’s speculation about alternate dimensions.
  • The influence of pulp science fiction on beliefs about flying saucers.
  • The rise of the “contactee” movement, with individuals like George Van Tassel and George Adamski claiming to have ridden aboard saucers and received messages from aliens.
  • The development of ufology as a parallel social movement, with figures like Frank Scully, Donald Keyhoe, and Leonard H. Stringfield publishing books and forming UFO investigation groups.
  • The emergence of UFO photography as a subgenre of documentary photography.
  • The eventual decline in popularity of the term “flying saucer” and its replacement by “UFO” and “UAP.”

Description 🔗

This section describes the characteristics and identification of flying saucers.

Identification 🔗

This subsection discusses the identification of reported flying saucers with known phenomena:

  • Experts have identified the majority of UFO reports as misidentifications or hoaxes.
  • Common explanations for saucer sightings include the planet Venus, weather phenomena, balloons, and airborne trash.
  • The US Navy’s Skyhook spy balloon project, which led to numerous misidentified sightings.
  • Psychological studies of why people believe in flying saucers, including Georges Heuyer’s view of the phenomenon as a shared delusion and Michel Monnerie’s psychosocial UFO hypothesis.

Reported sightings 🔗

This subsection summarizes the characteristics of reported flying saucer sightings:

  • Eyewitness descriptions differ in reported appearance, movement, and purpose.
  • Astronomer Donald Howard Menzel’s overview of flying saucers, noting the variety of shapes, sizes, colors, and movements reported.
  • The increasing standardization of alien descriptions over time, with Grey aliens becoming the most reported type of pilot.
  • The influence of popular social and cultural expectations on the details of claimed observations.

Fictional portrayals 🔗

This subsection discusses the portrayal of flying saucers in popular media:

  • Early portrayals emphasized high-speed maneuvers, while later media shifted to slowly hovering discs.
  • Examples of films and television series that feature flying saucers, such as The Flying Saucer, The Day the Earth Stood Still, and The Invaders.

Popular culture 🔗

This section explores the cultural impact of flying saucers.

Literature 🔗

This subsection discusses the appearance of flying saucers in literature:

  • Precursors to modern flying saucers appeared in science fiction literature, including The Shaver Mystery.
  • The emergence of a genre that treated fantastical stories as either true or plausibly true.
  • The use of advertisements to leverage cultural interest in flying saucers.
  • The appearance of aliens and flying discs in 1950s science fiction comics.

Film and television 🔗

This subsection discusses the portrayal of flying saucers in film and television:

  • Many early portrayals of flying saucers linked them to the Cold War.
  • Examples of films that feature flying saucers, such as The Thing from Another World, The Day the Earth Stood Still, and Earth vs. the Flying Saucers.
  • The adaptation of the flying saucer phenomenon by other countries, such as Japan and India.
  • The use of flying saucers in other genres, such as science fiction and comedy.

Architecture 🔗

This subsection discusses the use of flying saucer motifs in architecture:

  • The flying saucer as a symbol of 1950s culture.
  • The use of flying saucer motifs in Googie architecture and Atomic Age décor.
  • Notable flying saucer structures, such as Seattle’s Space Needle and Los Angeles International Airport’s Theme Building.
  • The influence of Googie architecture on the futuristic structures in the cartoon The Jetsons.
  • The use of the flying saucer as an architectural motif by Frank Lloyd Wright.
  • Examples of novelty architecture shaped like flying saucers, such as the Kielce Bus Station in Poland and the Spodek arena in Katowice, Poland.

Broader pop culture 🔗

This subsection discusses the broader cultural impact of flying saucers:

  • Flying saucers were a ubiquitous part of pop culture from 1947 into the mid-1970s.
  • The use of flying disc motifs in toys and other novelties, such as the frisbee and flying saucer candy.
  • The release of novelty songs about flying discs and alien invaders.
  • The appearance of flying saucers in video games, typically as antagonists.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_saucers

item.title: Levelland UFO case
item.description:
Levelland UFO Case 🔗

The Levelland UFO case occurred on November 2–3, 1957, around Levelland, Texas. It is considered a notable UFO incident due to the number of witnesses. The US Air Force attributed the sightings to ball lightning or a severe electrical storm.

Reports 🔗

On the evening of November 2, 1957, Pedro Saucedo and Joe Salaz reported a UFO sighting to the Levelland police department, claiming their truck’s engine died when a blue flash of light and a rocket-shaped object approached. Motorist Jim Wheeler reported a large, egg-shaped object blocking the road, causing his vehicle to stall. A married couple reported a bright flash of light that caused their headlights and radio to fail temporarily. Texas Technological College student Newell Wright encountered a 100-foot-long egg-shaped object that caused his car engine to sputter and die. Farmer Frank Williams reported a glowing object that caused his car’s lights and motor to stop. Ronald Martin and James Long also reported similar encounters with a brightly lit object. Sheriff Weir Clem saw a red object moving across the sky, and Fire Chief Ray Jones experienced vehicle malfunctions. The Levelland police department received a total of 15 UFO-related reports during the night.

U.S. Air Force Investigation 🔗

The Levelland sightings were investigated by Project Blue Book. An Air Force sergeant spent seven hours investigating, interviewing Saucedo, Wheeler, and Wright. The Air Force concluded that a severe electrical storm, possibly ball lightning or St. Elmo’s fire, caused the sightings and auto failures, blaming engine failures on wet electrical circuits. Donald H. Menzel agreed with the Air Force explanation, attributing the events to ball lightning.

Ufologists 🔗

James E. McDonald and J. Allen Hynek disputed the Air Force’s explanation, arguing that there was no electrical storm. McDonald testified that ten vehicles were stopped independently within a short area and time. Hynek concurred initially but later recognized the lack of evidence that ball lightning could stop cars and put out headlights. Ufologists also noted that the Air Force investigator did not interview nine of the fifteen witnesses.

Media Coverage 🔗

In March 2002, KDFW aired a report about the Levelland UFO case, interviewing Sheriff Weir Clem’s widow and friends.

See also 🔗

  • Lubbock Lights
  • List of UFO sightings

Further reading 🔗

Lists books and publications for further reading on the Levelland UFO case.

References 🔗

Lists the references cited in the article.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levelland_UFO_case

item.title: Time-traveler UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Time-traveler UFO hypothesis 🔗

The time-traveler hypothesis, also known as chrononaut UFO, future humans, extratempestrial model, and Terminator theory, proposes that unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are humans traveling from the future using advanced technology. This concept has gained recent attention from figures like retired NASA aerospace engineer Larry Lemke, Wisconsin congressman Mike Gallagher, and filmmaker Steven Spielberg. Mainstream scholars consider this hypothesis extremely implausible, and it’s generally viewed as unorthodox even among fringe conspiracy theorists.

Antecedents 🔗

This section explores the origins of the ideas that led to the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Origins of time travel speculation 🔗

This subsection traces the concept of time travel from the future to the past back to its literary origins. Pierre Boitard’s 1861 book Paris avant les hommes is credited with introducing the idea, featuring a man sent back to prehistoric Earth. Camille Flammarion’s 1887 novel Lumen also explored the theme of a soul traveling through different historical periods. The section also notes that while time travel is considered physically impossible by most, theoretical research continues to explore its potential feasibility, with scientists like J. Richard Gott and Ronald Mallet speculating on the possibility of future human time travel.

Speculation of future human evolution 🔗

This subsection discusses the history of speculation about the future evolution of mankind. It highlights H.G. Wells’ The Time Machine as an early example of both time travel and speculative evolution. Other authors mentioned include Edgar Rice Burroughs, Olaf Stapledon, Kurt Vonnegut, Stephen Baxter, and Cevdet Mehmet Kösemen. The section also identifies climate change, the technological singularity, space travel, and genetic enhancement as potential factors that could alter human evolution, leading to transhuman and posthuman scenarios.

UFOs and initial explanations 🔗

This subsection provides a brief overview of the history of UFO sightings. It mentions reports of unknown objects in the skies dating back to antiquity, as well as the mystery airship sightings of the 1890s and the Foo fighters and ghost rockets during World War II. The modern UFO era is said to have begun in the summer of 1947, following Kenneth Arnold’s sighting. Initial explanations for these sightings ranged from novel US or Soviet technology to misidentification of mundane objects and mass hysteria. Fringe theories included extraterrestrial or interdimensional origins.

Formation and spread 🔗

This section details the development and popularization of the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Implausibility of humanoid aliens 🔗

This subsection addresses the common depiction of aliens as humanoids in contactee and alien abduction folklore. It cites George Gaylord Simpson’s 1964 article The Nonprevalence of Humanoids, which argues that it’s unlikely for extraterrestrial intelligence to exist and even more unlikely for it to be humanoid. The section also mentions Stephen Jay Gould’s thought experiment about rewinding evolution, suggesting that humans would likely not evolve again. Biologist Jack Cohen’s view on the implausibility of Grey aliens evolving a physiology similar to humans is also included.

Modern popularization 🔗

This subsection explores the modern resurgence of the time-traveler hypothesis. It mentions Jacques Vallée’s 1975 book The Invisible College as an early example. Other figures and works mentioned include David S. Anderson, Jenny Randles, James Herbert Brennan, and Philip J. Corso and William J. Birnes’ The Day After Roswell, which reported Hermann Oberth’s belief that the Roswell craft could have been a time machine. The History channel series Ancient Aliens is also mentioned for its episodes exploring the concept. Michael P. Masters’ book Identified Flying Objects and The Extratempestrial Model are highlighted for their in-depth exploration of the hypothesis. Tim Peake and Steven Spielberg are mentioned for their recent public comments on the theory.

In popular culture 🔗

This subsection lists examples of the time-traveler hypothesis in popular culture. It includes the TV series It’s About Time, Gregory Benford’s novel Timescape, David Drake’s novel Birds of Prey, Michael Crichton’s novel Sphere, the TV film Official Denial, the comic book series Blake and Mortimer, the band Yes, Jordan Peele’s movie Nope, and the movie Interstellar.

Terminology and connection to other theories 🔗

This subsection clarifies the terminology used to describe the hypothesis, noting that while Michael P. Masters uses the term “extratempestrial,” the overall idea is often referred to as “the time-traveler hypothesis.” It also discusses the overlap between the time-traveler hypothesis and the interdimensional hypothesis, with figures like John Ventre and Harold E. Puthoff using the terms interchangeably. The section also notes that the time-traveler hypothesis provides an alternative explanation for the absence of future time travelers, similar to how the extraterrestrial hypothesis addresses Fermi’s paradox.

Criticism 🔗

This section presents criticisms of the time-traveler hypothesis. It notes that the hypothesis is considered pseudoscientific. Neil deGrasse Tyson is quoted as calling the hypothesis illogical, and Robert Sheaffer criticizes Michael P. Masters’ work for relying on the belief that time travel is possible. David J. Darling argues that the extraterrestrial and time-travel hypotheses are equally unlikely and unnecessary. Ian Ridpath suggests that Jim Penniston’s claims about time-traveling UFOs may have been influenced by the film Official Denial. Isaac Arthur is mentioned for debunking the concept as presented in Ancient Aliens. Fabio Costa is quoted as saying that time travel requires two doors, one in the future and one in the past, raising the question of where the time machine is.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including Time travel, Posthumanism, Transhumanism, Timeline of the far future, Longtermism, Speculative Evolution, Cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, Psychosocial hypothesis, Interdimensional hypothesis, and Space animal hypothesis.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-traveller_UFO_hypothesis

item.title: Westall UFO
item.description:
Westall UFO 🔗

The Westall UFO incident refers to a reported UFO sighting that occurred on April 6, 1966, in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. The event involved multiple witnesses, including students and a teacher from Westall High School. The incident has been commemorated through documentaries, reunions, and a UFO-themed playground.

Reports 🔗

On April 6, 1966, students and a teacher at Westall High School (now Westall Secondary College) reported observing a round, white, grey, or silver object with a domed top. The object reportedly descended behind trees into the Grange, an open area south of the school. Some accounts mention the object being pursued by five unidentified aircraft. Shaun Matthews, who was on vacation at the Grange, described the object as having a slight purple hue and being about twice the size of a family car.

Witness accounts varied, with some reporting the object taking off after landing, while others claimed it hovered. Students who went to the Grange after the sighting described a landing site with varying details, including a circle of grass described as burnt, “boiled,” or pressed down. The number of circles reported ranged from one to three. On April 9, 1966, air force personnel and UFO enthusiasts visited the field but found nothing of interest. The landowner subsequently burned the field to prevent further access.

Explanations 🔗

The Age newspaper initially suggested the object might have been a weather balloon released from Laverton. However, checks revealed that no commercial, private, or RAAF pilots reported anything unusual in the area.

Keith Basterfield proposed that a runaway balloon from the HIBAL high-altitude balloon project, used to monitor radiation levels after British nuclear tests at Maralinga, could be a likely explanation. He cited documents indicating a test balloon launched from Mildura may have drifted off course and landed near Westall High School. Basterfield noted that HIBAL balloons had a white silver appearance with a parachute and gas tube, consistent with witness descriptions. Reports also surfaced of “men in suits” cautioning witnesses against discussing the incident, suggesting a secret government exercise.

Brian Dunning suggested that a weather balloon could explain the initial sighting. He proposed that a nylon target drogue, towed by one plane for others to chase, could account for the second part of the event. Dunning also noted that over time, descriptions of the event have become mixed with fabricated details, making it difficult to discern accurate accounts.

Media Coverage 🔗

The documentary Westall ‘66 focuses on the sighting, featuring interviews conducted by ufologist Shane Ryan. Westall ‘66 has been incorporated into the national history curriculum as a lesson on critical analysis of popular portrayals of historical events. The Phenomenon, a documentary film directed and co-produced by ufologist James Fox, includes content related to the Westall UFO case.

Local Culture 🔗

A witness reunion was held at Westall Tennis Club Hall on April 8, 2006, to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the incident. The City of Kingston created Grange Reserve UFO Park at The Grange Reserve in Clayton South, featuring a silver UFO with red slides to reflect the 1966 Westall UFO Incident.

See also 🔗

  • Ariel School UFO incident
  • Australian Ufology
  • Bass Strait Triangle
  • Disappearance of Frederick Valentich
  • List of UFO sightings

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westall_UFO

item.title: 2006 O'Hare International Airport UFO sighting
item.description:
Chicago O’Hare UFO Sighting 🔗

This details a supposed paranormal event that occurred on November 7, 2006, around 4:15 p.m. at O’Hare International Airport. Twelve United Airlines employees and other witnesses reported seeing a UFO. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) dismissed the incident as a “weather phenomenon” due to the object not being detected on radar.

The Sighting 🔗

On November 7, 2006, at approximately 4:15 PM CST, a group of twelve airport employees at Chicago O’Hare International Airport reported witnessing a metallic, saucer-shaped craft hovering over Gate C-17. A ramp employee first spotted the object while pushing back United Airlines Flight 446, bound for Charlotte, North Carolina. The employee alerted the flight crew. Pilots, airline management, and mechanics also witnessed the object. Air traffic controllers did not see the object, and it did not appear on radar. Witnesses described the object as silent, dark gray, and ranging from 6 to 24 feet in diameter. Independent witnesses outside the airport also reported seeing the object. One witness described a disc-shaped craft hovering over the airport that shot through the clouds at high velocity, leaving a clear blue hole. Eyewitness accounts varied regarding the shape, height, movement, time, and number of objects sighted.

Reaction from the Federal Aviation Administration and United Airlines 🔗

Initially, both United Airlines and the FAA denied having information about the sighting. The Chicago Tribune filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, prompting the FAA to conduct an internal review of air-traffic communications tapes. The review uncovered a call from a United supervisor to an FAA manager in the airport tower regarding the UFO sighting. The FAA concluded that the sighting was due to a “weather phenomenon” and would not investigate further. Astronomer Mark Hammergren suggested that weather conditions were conducive to a “hole-punch cloud.” UFO investigators argued that the FAA’s refusal to investigate contradicted its mandate to investigate potential security breaches at airports. Some witnesses expressed frustration that federal officials declined to investigate the matter further.

Media Coverage 🔗

The Chicago O’Hare airport UFO story received coverage from major media outlets, including CNN, CBS, MSNBC, Fox News, the Chicago Tribune, and NPR. The History Channel’s UFO Hunters reviewed the incident in an episode titled “Aliens at the Airport” on February 11, 2009. The incident is also featured in Hangar 1: The UFO Files and Ancient Aliens.

In Popular Culture 🔗

The film UFO and an episode of Boston Legal reference the incident.

See Also 🔗

  • List of reported UFO sightings

References 🔗

This section lists the various sources cited in the article, including articles from the Chicago Tribune, History.com, and reports from NUFORC (National UFO Reporting Center) and NARCAP (National Aviation Reporting Center on Anomalous Phenomena).

External Links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources, including an interview with Chicago Tribune reporter Jon Hilkevitch and a Skeptoid podcast episode about the sighting.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_O%27Hare_International_Airport_UFO_sighting

item.title: UFO (Television Documentary Series)
item.description:
UFO (Television Documentary Series) 🔗

A four-part television documentary series about unidentified flying objects (UFOs). It was produced by J.J. Abrams’ production company, Bad Robot, and aired on Showtime in 2021.

Overview 🔗

This section introduces the documentary series, stating its genre as a television documentary, its subject matter as unidentified flying objects, the number of episodes (4), the production company (Bad Robot), and the original network (Showtime). It also mentions J.J. Abrams as the producer.

See also 🔗

This section contains a link to the “List of Showtime original programming” Wikipedia page.

References 🔗

This section lists the citations used in the article. These include:

  • A New York Times article by Alexis Soloski, titled “How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?”
  • A Daily Beast article by Nick Schager, titled “J.J. Abrams’ Mission to Expose the Truth About UFOs.”
  • A Paste article titled “Showtime’s Compelling UFO Docuseries Deserves to Be on Your Radar.”

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to the series’ page on IMDb (Internet Movie Database).
